Con este crédito D. 500 soles que será cancelado en 4 cuotas comprará carne D. diferentes animales y también menudencia.
Betsabe sueña con tener una carnicería muy granD..
texts.en:
Mrs. Betsabe C. Gormás is 45 years old and belongs to the Communal Bank “Dios Guía Nuestros Pasos” (God GuiD. Our Steps). She lives at Mz. J lote 6 Barrio 3B in El Provenir district, Trujillo city, La Libertad department, Peru. She completed second year of secondary school and then married at 17 years of age. She has 7 children, 6 sons and 1 daughter, 3 of whom are independent and 4 still depend on her. Betsabe buys and sells meat. She buys beef, veal, pork, chicken from the slaughterhouses and sells in a small stand in the Nuevo Futuro market in her neighborhood. With the first loan for 300 soles which was repaid in 4 payments, she invested in her business buying a little more beef and pork. With this loan for 500 soles, which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will buy different types of meat and also giblets. Betsabe dreams of having a very large butcher shop.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a variety of meat

loans.name: Jose Vicente

texts.es:
El señor José Vicente C. tiene la edad tiene 40 años de edad, su estado civil es acompañado, su compañera de vida no trabaja por lo que es ama de casa, Don José tiene seis hijos  con las siguientes edades su hijo mayor tiene la edad de 13 años y recientemente cursa el 1 año de secundaria, su otro hijo de 11 años cursa el 6 grado de primaria, su hija de 6 años cursa el 2 grado de primaria, y el varón de 4 años que cursa el kínder y el mas pequeño de 9 meses, los propósitos que tiene son de instalar su propio negocio en un lugar adecuado que represente las condiciones necesarias, otros de sus deseos es emplear a mas personas que le darán mayor productividad en la realización de sus productos como los son los zapatos y predominar fuertemente en el mercado.

La actividad económica a la que se dedica Don José es la elaboración de zapatos, el tiempo que tiene en este negocio es de 13 años, el da inicio a este negocio porque desde la edad de 13 años el aprendió este oficio quien ahora en adelante lo desempeña como una profesión para trabajar, su motivo de financiamiento es para capital de trabajo ya que necesita un local para la elaboración de sus productos por lo que en su casa de habitación no representa las condiciones necesarias, además tiene que realizar la compra de su materia prima como lo es la suela de los zapatos los viajes tiene que realizarlos hasta Masaya por lo que para el es importante la compra de la suela ya que de esta depende la realización de sus zapatos y la satisfacción de la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mr. José Vicente C. is 40 years old, and his civil status is accompanied. His partner doesn’t work because she is a housewife. Mr. José has 6 children of the following ages: his older son is 13 and recently completed his first year of secondary school; his other son, who is 11, finished his sixth year of primary school; his six-year-old daughter finished her second year of primary school; a four-year-old son, who is in preschool; and the youngest, who is 9 months old. His goals are to establish his own business in an appropriate location that meets the necessary conditions. He also wants to employ more people, who will give him more productivity in the production of his products like shoes, and to dominate strongly in the market.

Mr. José makes shoes. He has been pursuing this business for 13 years. He started this business because since he was 13 years old, he has learned this skill, which he now carries out as his profession. His motive for requesting this loan is for capital for his work since he needs a location for the production of his products and his home does not have adequate conditions. In addition, he has to buy the raw materials, like the soles for the shoes. He has to travel to Masaya because it is important for him to buy the soles, as both the production of the shoes and the satisfaction of the demand of his clients depend on them.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital for work

loans.name: Luis Alfonso

texts.es:
Mr. Luis Alfonso S. E. is 48 years old and he is married. Mr. Luis has three children, of whom two don’t depend on him. He has a young daughter, who is 3 years old and is not in school. His partner, Ruth de los Ángeles Rojas, works in a preschool. She also provides support to her family. His dreams are that he doesn’t lack work since he needs to provide his family with food every day. His other dreams are to set up his own workshop with his tools because this would give him more clients. He also wants to have a fixed location where the workshop can be located and to have a space where he can receive his clients and offer better service.

He repairs and paints automobiles; he has been in this business for 30 years. Mr. Luis began this business as an assistant in a mechanic workshop where he was able to learn about the different jobs that a mechanic does. What attracted his attention, though, was repairing and painting automobiles. As time passed, he succeeded in specializing in these tasks and, as a result, he decided to spend his life doing this work. He carried this out through service at home. He will use this loan for capital for work that he will use to purchase tools. This is feasible for him because the tools will be purchased in Managua. Thus he will be able to provide employees to the different assistants that he needs for the completion of different jobs.
texts.en:
El señor de nombre Luis Alfonso S. E. su edad es de 48 años su estado civil es acompañado, Don Luis tiene tres hijos de los cuales 2 varones no dependen de el solo su hija menor que tiene 3 años de edad y que no estudia, su compañera de vida de nombre Ruth De los Ángeles Rojas labora en un jardín de infancia y ella también proporciona su aportación a su familia, sus deseos son que el trabajo no le falte ya que Don Luis necesita de el para darle a su familia el alimento de cada día, otros de sus deseos es instalar su propio taller con sus respectivas herramientas por lo que esto le daría mayor afluencia de clientes y obtener un lugar fijo donde localizarlo y tener su espacio donde pueda recibir a sus clientes y brindar un mejor servicio. Su actividad económica es enderezar y pintar automóviles, el tiempo que lleva en este negocio es de 30 años, Don Luis inicia este negocio como ayudante en un taller de mecánica donde podía educarse en los diferentes oficios que tiene la mecánica, pero la que atrajo su atención fue la de enderezar y pintar automóviles y al paso del tiempo el logra destacarse en esta en particular y es así como decide implementarlo en su vida como un medio de trabajo y lo desempeña a través del servicio a domicilio, por lo que corresponde este financiamiento para capital de trabajo que será utilizado en la compra de equipos de sus herramientas ya que la compra se realiza en Managua pues esta resulta mas factible para el y así poder proporcionar empleos a los diferentes ayudantes que el necesita para la realización de los diferentes trabajos.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital de Trabajo

loans.name: Kham

texts.en:
Mrs. Kham T., 52, is a housewife who has five children, two of whom are married and live away from home. One of her daughters makes a living selling groceries, and uses her income to help support the family. Kham is married to Mr. Man Nit, who is 55 years old and makes a living repairing rice-threshing machines. He earns about $4 a day.

Kham hopes to enlarge her daughter’s business, and has applied for a $500 loan to buy more groceries. The loan will generate enough income to make payments while also improving the family's standard of living. The entire family lives in Resey Krok Commune, Banteay Meanchey Province.

loans.use: to buy more groceries

loans.name: Mann

texts.en: Mr. Mann Heum is a 44-year-old construction worker and is married to Mrs. Ry Hang, who is 46. The couple lives in Kotlokroam Commune, Siem Reap Province, and has five children, four of whom are in school. One of their children is married and no longer lives with tH.. Ry is a farmer but also makes mortar, which he sells from at his house and at construction sites. He earns about $3.25 a day.  He has applied for a loan of $400 to buy a secondhand motorcycle, which he will use to transport mortar.

loans.use: to purchase a secondhand motorcycle

loans.name: Morn

texts.en: Mrs. Morn H. is a 41-year-old farmer who lives in Koktlokler Commune, Siem Reap Province. She is the mother of four children, one of whom is married. One of her sons works for a local water company, while her husband, Mr. Khoeun Sngoun, 40, is also a farmer. The couple earns about $2 a day growing rice and vegetables. Morn has applied for a loan of $600 to buy oxen to plow her farm. This loan will make her work much easier and increase the value of her farm.

loans.use: to purchase oxen

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of a sewing machine for a tailoring business

loans.name: Mr. Roun Ry Group

texts.en: Mr. R. Rounm, 49 years old,  is the leader of a group of six businessman who live in the Chrouy Dang Village in Kandal Province. He is a farmer who cultivates rice on a small plot of land that he owns, while his wife, Mrs. Pan Mom, is a housewife. The couple has six children, four of whom are employed in different businesses, while the other two still attend school. To improve the fertility of his rice plantation, Mr. R. Rounm currently needs a loan to be able to purchase fertilizers and pesticides.

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizers and pesticides to improve land productivity

loans.name: Mr. Phallin Hak Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank loan group, consisting of 13 people, is based in the Boeng Krum Kraom Village in Kandal Province. Mr. Phallin H., 28 years old, is the president of the group and earns income driving a Tuk Tuk. His wife, Mrs. Phan Saron, is a garment factory worker. Unfortunately, Mr. Phallin H.'s business currently does not ensure enough income, because the motorbike needs to be repaired. He is therefore asking for a loan to be able to improve his business by fixing the motorbike. 
Village bank loans are mainly end-of-term loans. Three members have end-of-term loans, while others have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product, because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor, allowing thE. to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: Motorbike repair

loans.name: Mrs. Chanthorn Sray Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthorn S., 29 years old, has four children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school, while the youngest one is too young to study. Mrs. S. is the leader of a group of six businessmen who all live in the Andong Village in Kandal Province. She earns income breeding pigs, while her husband, Mr. Em Lok, works as a motorbike-taxi driver, make very little. Mrs. S.'s business, on the other hand, is going well, and she wants to expand it. Therefore, Mrs. S. is asking for a loan to buy additional piglets for breeding. 
This is a group loan mainly consisting of end-of-term loans. Three members of the group have end-of-term loans, while the others have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product, because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor, allowing them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term, and almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: Purchase of additional piglets for breeding

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en: Mrs. Sokha B. is a 30-year-old farmer who lives in Koktlokler Commune in Siem Reap Province. She has two children, both in school, and her husband, Mr. Ret Mei, 30, is also a farmer. They started their business in 1993, and Sokha is widely known in her area as an expert rice farmer. She would like to buy a cow to use for plowing, and has applied for a $125 loan to make that possible. Owning a cow will make her job much easier and allow her to improve her farm's output.

loans.use: to buy a cow

loans.name: Mr. Sorath Shem Village Bank Group

texts.en: The village bank loan group, based in the Chrouy Ampil Village, consists of nine people who all plan to use their loan share for different purposes. Mr. Sorath S. is the president of the group. He is not married and earns income as a motorbike-taxi driver in the local village. Currently, his business is experiencing difficulties, because the motorbike needs to be repaired. Therefore, Mr. Sorath is asking for a loan to be able to pay for the necessary repairs. He hopes to thereby increase his income and improve his living conditions.

loans.use: Motorbike repair

loans.name: Mrs. Pov Choek Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank loan group in the Andoung Russey Village in Kampong Chhnang Province consists of 8 people who all plan to use their loan share for different purposes. Mrs. Pov C., 29 years old, is widowed and has two children, both of whom attend a local school. She is the president of the loan group and earns income breeding pigs. Her business is going well, and she would like to expand it. Therefore, Mrs. Pov C. is asking for a loan to buy additional piglets for her business, thereby hopefully increasing her income. 
This is a village bank loan, mainly consisting of end-of-term (EoT) loans. Five members of the group have EoT loans, while the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product, because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor, allowing them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term, and almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: Purchase of piglets for breeding

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị Chút Group

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Chút năm nay 52 tuổi, Ms 01030013 là một phụ nữ rất chịu khó và vui tính. Chị luôn niềm nở với mọi người, nên được mọi người xung quanh cũng như khách mua hàng biết đến rất nhiều. Hàng ngày cả 2 vợ chồng chị đều bán hàng ăn như : Miến ngan, bún gà và hàng cơm phở …Ngoài ra chị còn làm thêm nghề xay sát bột cho trẻ em, còn con trai chị làm thợ điện, nên mức thu nhập của gia đình rất ổn định từ 200.000VNđ đến 220.000VNđ/ ngày. Chị rất thích tham gia vay vốn của chương trình nên hết chu kỳ chị lại tiếp tục đăng ký với mức vay 4.704.000VNđ để đầu tư vào cửa hàng của gia đình. 
 Trong nhóm chị có các thành viên sau :
Chị Nguyễn Thị N. Ms 01030012 vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để đầu tư vào cửa hàng bán xe đạp, đồ ăn chin. 
Chị Phan Thị Lý Ms 01030014 vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để mua nguyên liệu sản xuất kẹo.
Chị Nguyễn Thị V. Ms 01030015 vay mức 4.704.000VNđ mua dụng cụ sửa chữa máy tính. 
Chị Đặng Thị H. Ms 01030016 vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để mua gỗ sản xuất bàn ghế, tủ. 
Chị Nguyễn Thị T. Ms 01030028 vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để mua đồ trang điểm, cắt tóc.
Chị Đặng Thị

loans.use: to buy supplies for their businesses

loans.name: Laing

texts.en: Mrs. Laing L., 29, is a farmer who has worked on the land with her husband, Mr. Chomroeun Leyfor, the last 14 years. They live in Koktlokler Commune in Siem Reap Province and have two children, both of whom help out on the farm.  Mrs. Laing is applying for a $600 loan to buy oxen to help her plow her land and increase the size of her rice crop.

loans.use: To purchase oxen

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị Ngoan Group

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn thị Ngoan năm nay 45 tuổi Ms 01030004 là một phụ nữ rất năng động, hàng ngày chị làm nghề sửa chữa xe máy và chồng chị là thợ cắt tóc. Hiện tại chị có 2 con đi làm công nhân nên mức thu nhập của gia đình chị cũng khá ổn định từ 200.000VNđ/ ngày. Chị và nhóm đã tham gia vay vốn qua 2 chu kỳ đèu trả rất tốt, chị rất thích hình thức vay trả này vì nó giúp chị được trả dần, đồng thời tiết kiệm tiền để lo cho con cái chị có công việc làm ổn định. Chu kỳ này chị đăng ký vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để mua phụ tùng về bán và sửa chữa xe máy. Trong nhóm chị có các thành viên như sau: Chị Đặng thị N. Ms 01030001 vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để kinh doanh và sửa chữa điện thoại . Chị Lê thị Quý Ms 01030003 vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để kinh doanh hàng ăn sáng. Chị Đặng thị N. T. Ms 01030005 vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để mua đồ sửa chữa máy tính. Chị Nguyễn thị H. Ms 01030035 vay mức 4.704.000VNđ để kinh doanh và bán nước giải khát.

loans.use: invest in repair shops

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.en: Mavluda K. is a 55-year-old mother whose husband has no steady income. So, to cover day-to-day necessities, she is processing and selling dried apricots with the help of her daughter, who is pictured in the photo. She uses all the money she makes to care for her two children and provide for their education. Mavluda has six years of experience processing and selling dried apricots. She is very polite and considerate, and her clients are always very happy with the service they receive from her. Because her business is doing so well, she is increasing her net worth month by month. Today, Mavluda requests 2500 Somoni ($750) for the term of 9 months. She is going to use the loan for purchasing dried apricots with the purpose of processing them to increase her sales. With your help this will be possible. Mavluda and her daughter express their gratitude for everyone supporting them and promise to repay their loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: Buy dried apricots to process and sell

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en: Mrs. Sokhom C. is 46 years old, divorced and has four children, two of whom live at home. The other two work as fisherman, and the entire family lives in Koktlokroam Commune in Siem Reap Province. Sokhom is farmer who specializes in rice and vegetables. She is currently unable to support her family and has to rely on her children to get by. Also, her sons are not able to fish as much as they'd like because they lack the necessary equipment. Sokhom is seeking a $250 loan to buy her sons a boat. The loan will increase their income and allow them to have more to eat.

loans.use: to buy a small boat

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of additional grocery products for inventory

loans.name: Mukhtar

texts.en:
Five years ago Mukhtar started a dairy business. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, settled in Fuzuli region Kayidish village, which is built for IDPs. Mukhtar was born in 1966. He is married and has three children.

Now he needs a loan of 800 AZN (US$1,000) to buy a cow for improving his dairy business.

loans.use: He would like to buy a cow

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To request a loan to buy bamboo to tie with palm three in order to climb up the palm three to gather juice.

loans.name: Zebo

texts.en: Zebo N. is 35 years old. She is married and the mother of two adorable children. Zebo has a grocery store, which she runs herself, in addition to caring for her family and home. She began her small business 7 years ago with financial support from her husband, who has sold spare parts for automobiles for some time. The reason for starting the business was to increase her family’s income, and the business has been gradually growing ever since. In order to grow her business she requests a loan of 2500 Somoni ($750). Zebo is planning to use the loan to purchase a wider range of goods to sell. She promises to repay her loan within 5 months and thanks everyone who decided to support her.

loans.use: To increase the range of goods she sells

loans.name: Saodat

texts.en: Saodat O. is 50 years old. She’s married with five children, is a hard worker. Her husband had been earning a very low wage that didn't cover all the family's expenses, so he left for Russia two years ago to earn more money. That’s why Saodat saw that it was necessary to enter the family business. She began to sell  foodstuffs in her family grocery store, with the help of her younger son. The business is stable, and that allows her to improve the living condition of her family. Today, Saodat is asking for a loan of 1000 Somoni ($300), which she will use to offer a better service for her clients and improve the appearance of her store. She promises to pay back this amount in 8 months. She is thankful for the trust and aid that you offer her.

loans.use: To increase the range of foodstuffs she sells

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Farida H., 28 years old, lives in Dar es Salaam. She is single and has been running a cosmetics store selling beauty products since 1995. She works 12 hours a day, 7 days a week. Farida currently needs a loan of TSH 1,200,000 to be able to purchase additional cosmetics items for sale and thus expand her business. She is thankful to everyone for their support.

SELFINA has become a leading micro-credit supplier in Tanzania, providing loans through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Purchase of additional inventory for a cosmetics business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy a long bamboo to tie with the palm three for her child to climb up to gather palm juice.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma A., 42 years old, is from Dar es Salaam. She is married and has two children, 18 and 20 years old.  Since 2000, Fatuma has been earning income selling snacks on the street. She sells items such as samosas (meat and/or vegetables wrapped in a thin dough and deep fried) and vitafunwa (slightly sweetened, poofy, deep-fried pancakes made of rice flour). Fatuma works 1 to 4 hours a day, 6 days a week. Currently, she needs a loan of US$250 in order to purchase additional raw materials, including flour, in order to increase her production. Fatuma thanks everyone for their support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients for a food-sales business

loans.name: Dilfuza

texts.en: Dilfuza S. is 27 years old. She is married and the loving mother of two wonderful kids. Dilfuza’s husband is currently unemployed, so her business is the main source of income for her family. Dilfuza has a grocery store where she sells detergents, sweets, preserved food, juices, soft drinks and other foodstuffs. She has been in this business for 8 years. The inventory she has for sale is of very good quality and selection. Dilfuza is respectful and patient with all of her customers, which attracts people and brings them back to her shop to buy groceries again. Dilfuza is seeking to keep her business sustainable and has requested a loan of 2500 Somoni ($750) for the term of 9 months to increase the inventory she has for sale. One of her dreams is that her children raise their prospects through education. We believe this current loan will enhance the potential of her business and help Dilfuza reach all of her aspirations.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Rachana

texts.en: Mrs. Rachana S. is 27 years old and makes a living selling secondhand clothing outside of a local market. She has been doing this since 2000, and earns about $8.20 a day. Rachana is married and has one child. Her husband, Mr. Chomren Youn, is 28 years old and helps out with the business, which is doing very well. The family lives in Roloush Commune in Banteay Meanchey Province. Rachana would like to enlarge her business, and is applying for a $1,000 loan to buy more clothing to sell. The loan will increase her income and improve her family's life.

loans.use: to buy more clothing to sell

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina R. is 46 years old and lives in Dar es Salaam. She is married and has a child who is 25. Since 2002, Amina has been earning income running a mama lishe, a local restaurant or café in Tanzania that serves food such as ugali (hot, sticky dough made from maize flour) and plantains (cooked savoury banana), served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces.
Amina works 9 to 12 hours a day. Currently, she needs a loan of US$250 in order to purchase additional supplies for her restaurant, including mchele (uncooked rice) and maharage (beans). Amina thanks everyone for their support.

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients for a restaurant

loans.name: Christiner

texts.en:
Christiner F., 26 years old, is from Dar es Salaam. She is married and has two children, 2 and 7 years old.  

Christiner owns a business that sells kanga and vitenge, traditional clothing worn by Tanzanian women. Kanga is a piece of printed cotton fabric, often with a border along all four sides. It is printed using the silkscreen method with its pattern in frames. Kitenge (the Swahili plural is vitenge) is a piece of cotton fabric with wax print, printed using rotary printing machines. Kitenge is a communicating textile - the various colors, patterns, writings and symbols represent moods, feelings, cultures, and traditions of native African people.

Currently, Christiner needs a loan of US$125 in order to start a new business venture by opening a stand that would sell Coca Cola and other drinks that are popular even in the most remote villages in Africa. The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing; therefore, selling them has become a popular business venture. Chistiner thanks everyone for their support.

ABOUT SELFINA: 
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Investment in a new business venture

loans.name: Zarrina

texts.en: Zarrina S. is a very hardworking woman who knows that each day she has to give her best effort and all her courage. She is married and has a beautiful daughter. She raises and feeds animals with the goal of later selling them. She guides them into the field each day for feeding. This activity gives her satisfaction because it allows her to provide for a considerable amount of the household income. The care that she takes to feed the animals and supply them with occasional visits from the veterinarian has increased their population. She makes sure not to neglect her role as a mother, because she’s also very dedicated to lovingly raising her daughter. She wants to improve her stable stalls and produce milk in a quantity sufficient for selling it commercially. It is for this reason that she’s requesting a loan of 2500 Somoni ($750) for the term of 5 months to buy calves and feed for her animals. She is determined to change the course of her life with dedication and hard work.

loans.use: To buy calves and expand her business

loans.name: Tofig

texts.en:
Tofig has been in sheep breeding business for three years. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, settled in Fuzuli region, Bala Bahmanli village. Tofig was born in 1975. He is married and has two children.

Tofig needs a loan of 800 AZN (US$1,000) to buy 12 sheep for improving his sheep breeding business.

loans.use: To buy 12 sheep

loans.name: Costancia

texts.en:
Costancia M. is 45 years old and lives in Dar es Salaam. She is married and has two children, one of whom is already 24, while the other one is only 6 and a half years old. Additionally, she is responsible for taking care of two other children whose parents do not have the means to support the family. 
Costancia earns income through various businesses, including raising kuku (chickens), making baskets, and making vinyagos. 
Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. Kuku means chicken in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. The activity requires little start-up capital and space, and, while the chicken are growing, they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. 
Due to Costancia's business skills, she has also managed to develop a successful vinyagos-sales venture. A vinyago is a beautiful, hand-crafted statue made from wood by members of the Makonde tribe who come from southeastern Tanzania. Woodcarving is an important part of Makonde life, both in ancestor worship and in their own myth of creation. Their wooden statues are of three main types: traditional masks, motifs of female ancestor worship, as well as more abstract, modern forms.

Costancia works 9-12 hours a day, 6 days a week at her different enterprises with the assistance of one employee.  She currently needs a loan of US$550 in order to expand her businesses. Contancia thanks everyone for their support.

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase the range of goods she sells

loans.name: Nosirjon

texts.en: Nosirjon S. is 56 years old. He lives in the town of Isfara. He is married and has two children. His wife is a teacher at the local school. Nosirjon has been in the business of processing and selling dried apricots for 7 years. He also has his own orchard with 20 different types of apricot trees. Every year he makes dried apricots from his harvest. In addition, because of high demand for his products, he also purchases dried apricots form his supplier and sells them. Because he buys dried apricots wholesale, his prices are lower than regular market prices. He offers a wide assortment of dried apricots for clients of different means. All this allows Nosirjon to make his business quite successful, and it brings a stable income for the family. Now, because of a high demand for his goods, he wants to buy more dried apricots. For this purpose, Nosirjon requests 2500 Somoni ($750) for a term of 5 months. Nosirjon deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.

loans.use: To increase his stock of dried apricots

loans.name: Frank

texts.fr: Frank K. est un cultivateur de riz à Wome, un village situé à environ 130 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Âgé de 43 ans Frank est marié et père de 3 enfants. Avec ce crédit il désire augmenter son espace cultivable en prenant des métayers et aussi en achetant des insecticides et  herbicides. Il compte sur cette chance pour avoir un meilleur rendement, source de l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Frank K. is a rice producer in Wome, a village located approximately 130 kilometers from Lomé, the capital of Togo. He's 43 years old, married, and the father of 3 children. With this loan, he wishes to increase his cultivable area, by hiring farmers and by buying insecticides and herbicides. He counts on this opportunity to obtain a better yield, in order to improve the living conditions of his family.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To hire farmers and to buy herbicides and insecticides

loans.name: Mrs. Bet You Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Bet Y., is 53, and the mother of a child who is employed in a garment factory. Her husband Beong Thet is a driver who makes a small salary to help support his family.  Bet earns her living as a farmer who cultivates rice on 1-hectar field. She is facing a problE. on her plantation because her field is infertile, which produces bad crops. To solve this problE., is asking for a loan to purchase additional fertilizers to help make her field more productive. 

Bet is a village bank president of sixteen people who all live in Meun Trea Village in Kadal Province.
This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Thirteen members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows thE. to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on KiV..

loans.use: To ask for a loan to purchase fertilizers to support her field to make it more productive.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema M., 38 years old, is from Dar es Salaam. She is married and has two children, 11 and 15 years old.  Since 2004, Rehema has been running a grocery store, where she sells general items, including onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. Rehema's store is popular among the local people, especially at times when they need one or two missing ingredients for cooking the evening meal and don’t have time to go all the way to the market.

Rehema works 9 to 12 hours a day, 6 days a week and is assisted by her husband. She currently needs a loan of TZH 770,000 in order to purchase additional inventory for her store, such as juice and soda. Rehema thanks everyone for supporting her.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Purchase of inventory in bulk for a grocery store

loans.name: Dilshoda

texts.en: Dilshoda U. is 28 years old. She is married with two children. Since she was a young girl, Dilshoda has helped her mother with her clothing sales business. Four years ago, Dilshoda began selling towels and different kinds of dishes in the store, since her husband’s income was not enough to cover their family expenses. That was how she got a taste of the business and found that it earned her sufficient income. Currently, she works in this business full time, and thanks to her enthusiasm, she has made a name for herself in the market. However, her clients request more and more things each day, which is why Dilshoda is requesting a loan of 1000 Somoni ($300), which she will repay within a 6-month term. With this money, Dilshoda will be able to purchase more towels and dishes and thereby give her business a boost. With your help, Dilshoda will be able to help her children prosper and go to school.

loans.use: To buy more towels and dishes to sell

loans.name: Magdalene

texts.en: Magdalene O. sells clothes, body creams, and cosmetics. She is 37 years old and married with 4 children. She has been in this business for a long time. She hawks her goods from street to street by carrying the goods on her head in a large tray. This is difficult and tedious. She needs the loan amount of N52,000 to purchase a wheelbarrow that will enable her to hawk her goods more easily. She also wants to buy more creams and clothes to sell. She expresses her gratitude to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes, creams, and a wheelbarrow to transport her goods

loans.name: Komi

texts.fr: Komi A. est âgé de 23 ans, célibataire sans enfants. Il est propriétaire depuis 2 ans d’une boutique à Wome, un village situé à environ 130 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Pour augmenter la capacité de sa boutique, Komi veut approvisionner sa boutique en achetant des sacs de riz, des cartons de boîtes de conserves et ainsi que des cartons de savons. Il espère amèliorer les conditions de sa vie avec cette opportunité
texts.en:
Komi A. is 23 years old, single, and has no children. For the past two years, he has been the owner of a shop in Wome, a village situated about 80 miles from Lomé, the capital of Togo. To increase his shop's capacity, Komi wants to stock up on sacks of rice, boxes of canned goods, and boxes of soap. He hopes to improve his living conditions with this opportunity.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise for resale

loans.name: Choun

texts.en: Mrs. Choun N. is 26 years old and lives in Speu Commune in Kompong Cham Province. She is a farmer, and has grown rice and vegetables for many years while her husband, Mr. Chanra Vann, 27, both farms and drives a horse-cart. Chanra leaves home early every morning to pick up customers or merchandise in various parts of his commune, returning in the afternoon. He earns about $2 a day. Unfortunately, Chanra's horse is often sick. His wife is applying for a loan of $325 so that they can buy a new horse to replace the old one.

loans.use: to buy a horse

loans.name: Makhsudakhon

texts.en: Makhsudakhon U. is a 60-year-old woman. She is a widow and has two adult children. She has survived despite difficult circumstances thanks to her optimism, and she strives above all to care for her children. Makhsudakhon is a teacher, but when her husband passed away she decided to run her own business so as to be able to cover all the expenses of her family. She rented a small store on the main street of her neighborhood and stocked it with kitchen inventory. She started out 10 years ago with only $20 in capital. Gradually she expanded her business, and currently she has about $5,000 in capital. Now Makhsudakhon feels that with more working capital the shop could generate more income, so she is asking for a loan of 2000 Somoni ($600) to jump-start the business and raise the family's standard of living. She promises to repay the loan within 6 months.

loans.use: To increase inventory in her kitchen store

loans.name: Anani

texts.fr: Anani G. est âgé de 37 ans, marié et père de 2 enfants. Il est meunier depuis 10 ans à wome, un village situé au nord-ouest de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. il  désire par ce crédit acquérir son propre moulin et gagner plus de fonds pour mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Anani G. is 37 years old, married, and the father of two. He has been a miller for ten years in Wome, a village located northwest of Lomé, the Togolese capital. He would like to use this loan to acquire his own mill and to earn more money to provide for his family better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a mill

loans.name: Eruchalu

texts.en: Eruchalu O.  sells upholstery materials. He says that this business is a lucrative one. O. is 27 years old and he is single. He travels to Onitsha's main market to purchase upholstery materials to sell in Benin City. He needs the loan amount of N102,000 to purchase more upholstery materials to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support and to LAPO MICROFINANCE for their business training.

loans.use: To purchase more upholstery materials to sell

loans.name: Regina

texts.en: Regina K. is 33 years old and married with 2 children.  She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is carrying her baby in this picture.  She sells provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs.  She will use the loan amount of N52,000 ($450 US) to purchase more drinks, provisions, and foodstuffs to sell.  She is grateful to all Kiva lenders and LAPO Microfinance for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, provisions and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Rebeka

texts.en:
Rebeka B., 31 years old, is from Dar es Salaam. She is married and has five children, all between the ages of 7 and 15. Additionally, Rebeka is responsible for supporting one other dependant whose parents, unfortunately, died of HIV/AIDS. Since last year, Rebeka has been earning income selling cooking oils. She purchases oil from the city of Singida, where it is cheap, and transports and sells it in Dar es Salaam at a higher price. Rebeka works 5-8 hours per day and currently needs a loan of US$250 in order to expand her business. She is thankful to everyone for their support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Purchase of cooking oil for resale

loans.name: Saiyora

texts.en: Saiyora U. is married, and her husband works as a laborer. Together they have two children. She started her business to help the family make ends meet. The little income her husband earned was not enough to subsist or lead a better quality of life. She started four years ago with a little stand where she sold kitchen supplies, and ultimately she opened her own store, which she still runs today. Gradually she expanded her business and currently she has $4,500 in capital. Her daily income is about 100 Somoni. Now Saiyora wants to expand her business and purchase additional kitchen inventory for her store. For this purpose, she is requesting a loan of 2000 Somoni ($600) for the term of 6 months. With this expansion, she hopes to earn more and thus to be able to meet all the needs of her children.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of kitchen supplies

loans.name: Dalini

texts.en:
Dalini A., 26 years old, is from Dar es Salaam. She is divorced and has two children, 5 and 8 years old.  Additionally, she is responsible for supporting another child. Dalini has been running a snack stand since last year.  She sells items such as soda, water, and chipisi (French fries) on the side of the road.  
Dalini works 9 to 12 hours a day, 6 days a week. She now needs a loan of US$250 in order to expand her business.  Dalini is thankful to everyone for supporting her.

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Tho's Group

texts.en:
K. Tho is 28 years old and the mother of two children. One child is in school, and the other is three years old. K. is a vegetable seller in the local market. Her husband Sambath Chea, helps her in the current business. Her business is going well, and she wants to expand it so she has asked for a loan to buy different kinds of vegetable to re-sell to her customers. 
K. is a group leader of four who all live in Tuol Thma Village in Kampong CH. Province.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy different kinds of vegetable to re-sell to her customers.

loans.name: Kodjo

texts.fr: Kodjo A. est un vaillant commerçant à Womé, un village situé à environ 130 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Âgé de 45 ans, il est marié et père de 5 enfants. Etant donné que la demande de sa clientèle devient de plus en plus exigeante, Kodjo désire avec ce crédit alimenter sa boutique pour répondre aux besoins de la clientèle. Il va dans le même sens une augmentation de ses profits et par là une amélioration de ses conditions de vie.
texts.en:
Kodjo A., 45, is a hard-working businessman in Womé, a village situated about 130 km from Lomé, the Togolese capital. He is married and the father of 5 children. Since his customers' demands are becoming more and more exigent, Kodjo wants this loan to restock his shop to respond to the needs of his clientele. With this done, he will also see an increase in his profit and thus an improvement in his living conditions.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase merchandise to re-sell

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en: Christopher A. sells building materials like cement.  He is 37 years old and married with 4 children.  Christopher and his family live in Benin city, Edo State, Nigeria.  He is a LAPO client.  Christopher has his store located in a strategic place in Benin City.  He needs the loan amount of N52,000 ($450 US) to purchase more bags of cement to sell.  He says a big thank you to Kiva lenders and LAPO Microfinance for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase cement to sell.

loans.name: San

texts.en: San T. is 32 years old and the mother of five children. San is a villager in Lvea Sor Kandal Village in the Kandal Province. She is farmer who has a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Ning Sareth, is a motorbike taxi driver who makes a small income to support his family (he is presented on the right of the photo). She faces a problem on her plantation because her field is infertile which affects her crops. She is asking for a loan to buy more fertilizer to help make her crops more productive.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to support the field to make her crop more productive.

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha S. is 50 years old and lives in Dar es Salaam. She is married and has four children, all between the ages of 20 and 34. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two other dependants. 
Mwanaisha is a wonderful woman who has devoted her career to the care and education of Tanzania's youth. She nurtures young children and prepares them to enter elementary school. Mwanaisha is very dedicated, working 9 to 12 hours a day, 5 days a week. At present, she needs a loan of US$250 in order to make renovations to the nursery school, for instance, by purchasing and installing additional desks for her students. Mwanaisha is thankful to everyone for their support.

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Renovations to a nursery school

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence A. is 49 years old and married with 7 children.  She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.  Florence sells bed sheets and shoes for children and adults.  She sells in an open area on the Ring road in Benin City.  She needs the loan amount of N102,000 to purchase more bed sheets and shoes to sell and also to rent a store.  She is grateful to Kiva lenders and LAPO Microfinance for their financial support.

loans.use: To rent a store and purchase bed sheets and shoes for merchandise.

loans.name: Shahnoza

texts.en: Shahnoza N. is 19 years old. She is not married and lives with her parents. Shahnoza is a market vendor. She sells women's clothing in the local market. After finishing the school she started her own business because she needed money to help her parents pay for household and personal expenses. Shahnoza has been in this business for 4 years already. In these years she has managed to make her business stable and profitable, generating a steady income for her family and allowing her to support her parents. Now Shahnoza is planning to expand her business, and in order to do so, she’ll need to increase her working capital to purchase new autumn clothing for sale. With this purpose, Shahnoza requests 2500 Somoni ($750) for a term of 9 months. She promises to repay the loan promptly and thanks all supporting her.

loans.use: To buy new fall clothes for sale

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience O. sells yams at Use market in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.  She buys the yams from the north.  She is 50 years old and married with 6 children.  She and her family live in Benin City.  The demand for yams in Nigeria is high because it is a staple food.  She needs the loan amount of N102,000 to purchase more yams to sell.  She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase yams to sell.

loans.name: Mrs. Sophal Morn Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Sophal M. is 27 years old, and the mother of two children. She is a garment factory worker, while her husband, Chaing ChH., is a fisherman who gathers fish. Chaing's motor boat is very old and needs to be replaced. Sophal is asking for a loan to buy a new boat motor for her husband's business. 
Sophal M. is a village bank president of a village bank loan which consists of seventeen people. It is located in PrE. Samraong Village in Kandal Province and all the members will use the loan for different purposes.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy a new boat motor for her husband business.

loans.name: Caro

texts.en: Caro O. sells drinks in her store.  She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.  She is 51 years old and married with 5 children.  She buys drinks from distributors in Benin City.  She needs the loan amount of N52,000 to purchase more drinks to sell.  She hopes to be a major distributor of drinks in future.  She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Benkadi (Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre (4) femmes du groupe Benkadi,  toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et  4 enfants vivent dans des grandes familles traditionneles à Sanoubougou II, le centre ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali) se sont connue à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage. Très dynamiques et experimentées, ces femmes se sont spécialisées dans le commerce  de pagnes wax, de bazins(tissus très prisés en Afrique de l’ouest), de tasses de différentes sortes, du riz et des produits de beauté. 
Ce groupe dans le soucis de satisfaire le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter a décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso à travers une association des femmes de son quartier (Assiciation SOLEIL de Sanoubougou II) et est à son troisième prêt solidaire (prêt du groupe) après avoir correctement remboursé les prêts précédents.
Elles s’approvisionnent dans la ville de Sikasso et environnants et à Bamako.
Avec ce premier prêt, elles comptent acheter 10 pièces de pagne wax, 10 pièces de bazins,  4 jeux tasse, 6 sacs de riz et 15 cartons de pommade, de gel pour les cheveux, de crème pour la  peau etc. 
Les produits sont vendus en détail, au comptant et à crédit aux marchés et de façon ambulante  dans la ville de  Sikasso à une clientèle composée très généralement des femmes. 
 Elles espèrent réaliser chacune avec ce troisième prêt un bénéfice moyen de 20.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utiliser pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir  aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités respectives.
texts.en:
The four women of the Benkadi group, all of whom are married and 30 years old on average with 4 children living in big traditional families in Sanoubougou II, the central city of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali), met each other through family and neighborhood connections. Very energetic and experienced, these women specialized in “pagnes wax” (traditional wrap-arounds), damask (a prized fabric in West Africa), different kinds of containers, rice, and beauty products. In order to satisfy the needs of its ever-increasing clientele, the group decided to incorporate the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso through a local women’s association (Association SOLEIL de Sanoubougou II) and is on its third united loan (group loan) after having properly repaid the preceding loans. They stock up in the city of Sikasso and surrounding areas and in Bamako. With this loan, they intend to buy 10 pieces of “pagnes wax,” 10 pieces of damask, 4 sets of containers, 6 sacks of rice, and 15 boxes of pomade, hair gel, lotion, etc. The products are sold at retail, for cash or credit in markets and while traveling in the city of Sikasso to a clientele composed generally of women. They hope to each make an average of 20,000 FCFA per month with this 3rd loan, which will be used to make loan payments and meet the needs of the family; the rest will be invested in respective businesses.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various items (pagnes Wax, damask, containers, rice, and beauty products)

loans.name: Afeafa

texts.fr: Afeafa G. est revendeuse des bananes plantains à Wome, un village situé à environ 130 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Âgée de 35 ans, mariée et mère de 2 garçons, elle exerce cette activité depuis 5 ans et cela consiste à acheter les bananes auprès des agriculteurs pour les revendre dans la capitale. Elle est passionnée par ce commerce et désire par ce crédit accroître la capacité de son activité
texts.en:
Afeafa G., 35, sells plantains in Womé, a village situated about 130 km from Lomé, the Togolese capital. She is married and the mother of 2 sons, and she has been working at this business for 5 years. She buys the plantains from the growers to re-sell in the capital. She is passionate about this business and wants this loan to grow the capacity of her undertaking.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying plantains for re-sale

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana O.  lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is 42 years old and married with 7 children. She owns a store where she sells drinks and wine. She needs the loan amount of N81,000 to purchase more drinks and wine to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and wine to sell

loans.name: Koan's Group

texts.en:
Koan E. is 36 years old and the father of two children. He and his wife, Yoem Da, are farmers who own 0.5-hectar field.  They cultivate rice for a living. Since they have only one plantation, Koan cannot support his family well so he is asking ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding and hopes to increase his income after he sells his cow. 
Seven people in Ba Khong Khang Kaeut Village in Takeo Province are made up the village bank loan. Koan is the village bank president. 
This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Five members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Mavlyuda

texts.en: Problems and money shortages never defeated Mavlyuda, who has always looked for a way to get past obstacles and continue to improve her situation. Mavlyuda is an extremely hardworking and energetic woman. She is 50 years old. She is divorced and the loving mother of two children. She began her business to keep herself busy and active when she found herself sad and depressed due to her separation, and also in order to have an independent income. For more than 6 years, she has operated a store where she sells women’s clothing. As a rule she travels to the neighboring town to get new garments at very cheap prices. Her store is well known, and people love to visit because it's clean, tidy, and run by someone who is very kind and thoughtful. Mavlyuda hopes that her store will keep growing so that she can maintain a comfortable life for her family, especially for her children. To make that possible, she has applied for a new loan that she will use to buy more clothing to sell. Mavlyuda requests 2500 Somoni ($750) for a term of 9 months. She promises to repay the loan promptly, as she has with previous loans.

loans.use: To buy new clothes to sell

loans.name: Sohpia

texts.en:
Sohpia M., 35 years old, is from Dar es Salaam. She is married and has three children, all between the ages of 3 and 14.   
Sophia earns income running her own business that sells kanga and vitenge, traditional clothing worn by Tanzanian women. Kanga is a piece of printed cotton fabric, often with a border along all four sides. It is printed using the silkscreen method with its pattern in frames. Kitenge (the Swahili plural is vitenge) is a piece of cotton fabric with wax print, printed using rotary printing machines. Kitenge is a communicating textile - the various colors, patterns, writings and symbols represent moods, feelings, cultures, and traditions of native African people.
In order to make additional income, Sophia has also opened a snack shop, where she sells items such as samosas (ground meat and/or vegetables wrapped in a thin dough and deep fried) and vitafunwa (slightly sweetened, poofy, deep-fried pancakes made of rice flour). 
Sophia has been running her vitenge and snack shops since 2000. At present, she needs a loan of US$250 in order to increase the profits of her business by purchasing additional stock in bulk. Sophia thanks everyone for their support.

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Purchase of additional stock in bulk

loans.name: Solomon

texts.en: U. Solomon sells motor and electrical spare parts.  He started this business after his secondary school education.  He is 28 years old and married without children.  He needs the loan amount of N81,000 to purchase more motor and electrical spare parts to sell.  He says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase motor and electrical spare parts to sell.

loans.name: Cesiri (Redoubler D’Efforts) Group

texts.fr:
Cesiri est un regroupement de six femmes mariées ayant en moyenne 30 ans et de 3 enfants et vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies à Sanoubougou II de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Liées par des relations d’amitié et de voisinage, elles font le commerce de pagnes wax, de bazins, du bois de chauffe, de tissus brodés et de savons de fabrication locale.
Dans le souci d’augmenter la taille de leurs entreprises, ces femmes ont décidé ensemble d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement remboursé son premier prêt solidaire, ce groupe de l’association Soleil  de Sanoubougou II,  est à son deuxième prêt. Qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 5 sacs de savons de fabrication locale, 30 mètres de tissus brodés, 15 pièces de pagne wax, 2 chargements de camion “10Tonnes”en bois de chauffe et  24 mètres de bazins(moins riches).
Les femmes du groupe Cesiri ont comme principales sources d’approvisionnent possibles les villes de Sikasso et de Bamako(capitale de la république du Mali). Les produits sont vendus en détail, au comptant et à crédit dans les différents marchés de la ville de Sikasso et de façon ambulante dans les quartiers à une clientèle contituée généralement de femmes. Elles espèrent réaliser chacune  un bénéfice moyen de 25.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt et les conjoints à subvenir  aux besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
Cesiri is an association of six married women who are on average 30 years of age with three (3) children. They live in large traditional families in Sanoubougou II in the city of Sikasso ( third administrative region in the Republic of Mali). Joined by reasons of friendship and neighbors, they are in the business of selling wax pagne (decorative cloth), bazin (undyed fabric), fire wood, embroidered fabric and locally made soaps.

In an effort to increase the size of their enterprise, the women had decided to associate with the Soro Yiriwaso microbank. After successfully completing their first loan, this group, which is part of the "Soleil de Sanoubougou II", has taken out a second loan, which will be used to purchase, 5 sacks of locally made soap, 30 meters of embroidered fabric, 15 pieces of wax "pagne", 2 truck loads (10 ton trucks) of fire wood and 24 meters of fabric (medium quality).

The women of the Cesiri group usually use the cities of Sikasso and Bamako ( capital of the Republic of Mali ) as their principal source of products. These products are sold at retail for cash or credit at the various markets in the city of Sikasso and door to door around the neighborhoods to a clientele made up mostly of women. They each hope to earn an average profit of 25,000 francs CFA per month which would be used to make the loan payments and assist their husbands in meeting family expenses.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase various small business products such as: wax "pagne" (dcorative cloth), fabric (medium quality), firewood, embroidered fabric and locally made soaps.

loans.name: Mrs. Kim Huoy Lach Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Kim Houy L. is 26 years old and the mother of two children. Her husband, Saom Mom, is a farmer who owns a 0.7-hectar plantationand cultivates rice for a living.  Kim is a poultry breeder and has raised about 40 ducks and chickens in her own house. Since this business is going well, she would like to expand it. She is asking for a loan to buy more poultry for breeding. 

The village bank which consists of fourteen people is located in Ba Khong Khang Kaeut Village in TaK. Province and all the members will use the loan for different purposes. 
This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Nine members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more poultry for breeding.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet A. is 38 years old and married without children.  She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.  She owns a store where she sells drinks, provisions, and foodstuffs.  Juliet does not have a deep freezer to cool her drinks to sell, and her customers go to other stores to buy cold drinks.  She needs the loan amount of N81,000 to buy a deep freezer to cool her drinks.  She will also use some part of the loan to buy more provisions to sell.  She says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and a deep freezer.

loans.name: Dotse

texts.fr: Dotse T. est âgé de 41 ans, marié et père de 2 enfants. Il est conducteurs de taxi moto depuis 2 ans à Wome, un village situé au nord-ouest de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Sa moto ayant servi durant deux années, elle paraît usée, et monsieur Dotsè souhaite par ce crédit acheter une nouvelle moto pour relancer son activité.
texts.en:
Dotse T. is 41 years old, married, and the father of 2 children. He's been a motorcycle taxi driver for 2 years in Wome, a village northwest of Lomé, the capital of Togo. His motorcycle has been in use for two years and appears used up. Mr. Dotse is therefore seeking this loan to buy a new motorcycle in order to reinvigorate his business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en:
Gabriel has a restaurant at Uselu Motor Park. He is standing next to his wife in the picture. He sells cooked foods like rice, beans, yam, eba, etc. He also sells drinks in his restaurant. His restaurant is always busy with his customers. Travelers always stop by his restaurant to buy cooked foods. He manages the restaurant with his wife. They buy drinks from distributors in Benin City.

Gabriel needs the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell to his customers. He is 40 years old and married with 4 children. He and his family live in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. He says "thank you" to all Kiva lenders and LAPO Microfinance for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Vuthy

texts.en: Vuthy K. is 36 years old and the father of two young children. His wife, Chim Phary, is a fish seller. Vuthy is a villager in the Preak Samraong Village in Kandal Province. He is a vegetable farmer and gets a small revenue from his 0.4-hectar plantation, which is a small plot of land. Vuthy would like to expand his plantation so he is asking for a loan to buy another piece of land to cultivate.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy a piece of land to cultivate.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth O. owns a restaurant where she sells cooked foods like rice, beans, amala (a dish made from ground, dried yams), pepper soup, and drinks. She is 40 years old and married with 5 children. She is a LAPO client. She is requesting the loan amount of N52,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Horonkantigui (Crédibilité Group

texts.fr:
Horonkantigui est un regroupement composé de 9 femmes toutes mariées ayant en moyenne 42 ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent dans le village de Kafela situé à  20km de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Unies par des liens socio économiques, les femmes de ce groupe font l’achat et la vente des condiments alimentaires  et du charbon de bois.
Etant l’un des plus anciens groupes de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso (6 ans de collaboration), il a eu 12 prets solidaires et tout ceux ci ont été remboursés correctement. Elles comptent avec ce prêt acheter, 400 sacs de charbon et un  stock de condiments alimentaires (2 sacs d’oignon, 2 sacs d’aubergine, 1 sac de gombo, 5 d’aromes, 5 boîtes de concentré de tomate, etc.).
Elles s’approvisionnent exclusivement dans les villages environnants de Kafela (tels Finkolo, Farako etc.)auprès des producteurs ayant des exploitations agricoles et forestières (c’est à dire detenteur d’un permis de coupe de bois). Ces femmes profitent des jours de la foire de Sikasso où il y’a une disponibilité de vehicules de transport pour acheminer leurs marchandises au grand marché de la ville. Elles effectuent leurs ventes au comptant et en détail (souvent  en gros)  à une clientèle composée très généralement des femmes et surtout des forains venant des grandes villes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 16.000 FCFA par mois qui servira essentiellement à renforcer le fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
Horonkantigui is a group of nine women, all marrried, who average 42 years of age and five children. They live in the village of Kafela, located 20 km from the city of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Linked by socio-economic ties, the women of this group buy and sell condiments and charcoal. As one of the oldest groups of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso (six years of collaboratiion), it has had twelve solidarity loans that have all been correctly repaid. The group members intend to use this loan to buy 400 sacks of charcoal and a stock of condiments: 2 sacks of onions, 2 sacks of eggplants, 1 sack of okra, 5 sacks of flavorings, 5 cans of tomato paste, etc. They get their supplies exclusively in villages surrounding Kafela (such as Finkolo, Farako, etc.) from producers having farm and forest operations (that is, holders of wood-cutting permits). These women take advantage of Sikasso market days where there is transportation available to take their goods to the grand marketplace of the city. They make their sales in cash at the retail level (often wholesale) to customers composed generally of women and especially of market vendors from big cities. They each envision realizing an average profit of 16,000 francs CFA per month, which will serve essentially to boost their working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments and charcoal

loans.name: Mrs. Samrith Mom Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Samrith M. is 35 years old and the father of four He is a motorbike taxi driver who makes a small income to support his family. His wife, Hun Saron, is a farmer who owns a 0.7-hectar rice plantation. Although Samrith and Hun have different businesses, they still cannot support their family. Samrith has decided to ask for a loan to help build a new house for their household. 

Samrith is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. Ten people who are living in Damnak RovI. Village in Takeo Province are made up the village bank loan and they plan to use the loan for different purposes.
This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Seven members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows tH. to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to add to her saving to build a new house for her household.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria O. is 30 years old and married with four children. She sells clothes at the Uselu market in Benin City in Edo State, Nigeria. She sells women's clothing only.

Gloria is a hardworking woman and she is determined to lift her family above poverty. She needs the loan for N52,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. She says a big thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Mrs. Pok Khiev Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Pok K. is a 68, and is married to Kuy S. who is a rice farmer. She owns a small grocery store in the local village. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it so she is asking for a loan to buy more grocery products for her inventory. This will help increase her output and sales.

The village bank which consists of ten people is located in Damnak Rovieng Village in Takeo Province and Pok K. is a village bank president. This is a village bank loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Seven members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more grocery products for her inventory.

loans.name: Sophy

texts.en: Sophy P. is 27 years old and the mother of two children.  Her husband (located right in the picture), Kong Vanny, is a traditional healer who makes a small income to support the family. Sophy is a villager in the Ta Saom Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer and a cow breeder. Since the cow breeding business is going well, she would like to expand it, and is asking for a loan to buy one more cow for breeding.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy one more cow for breeding.

loans.name: Jigignouma (Sûre Espoir) Group

texts.fr:
Spécialisées dans le commerce d’articles divers tel que les pagnes wax, bazins moins riche(tissus très prisés en Afrique), chaussures, porte monnaies, bois de chauffe, sucre, lait, spaghetti et tissus brodés, les cinq (5) femmes du groupe Jigignouma (toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 31 ans et de 4 enfants) vivent dans des grandes familles traditionneles à Sanoubougou II, le centre ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali).

Les femmes de ce groupe Jigignouma de l’association Soleil de Sanoubougou II sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire (prêt du groupe) avec Soro Yiriwaso. Tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. Elles sollicitent ce troisième prêt pour pouvoir acheter, 1 sac de sucre, 3 cartons de lait, 1 carton de spaghetti, 3 cartons de savon, 3 pièces de tissus brodés, 2 pièces de bazin, 3 pièces de pagne wax, 1 chargement de camion “10 Tonnes” en  bois de chauffe, 10 paires de chaussures et 10 portes monnaies.
Les villes de Bobo Dioulasso en Burkina Faso, de Bamako et de Sikasso au Mali sont les principales sources d’approvisionnent de ces femmes. Elles vendent leurs marchandises au marché de la ville de Sikasso (et queques fois de façon ambulante dans les quartiers) en gros, en détail, au comptant et à crédit.  Certaines femmes envoient leurs marchadises à Abidjan(république de la Côte d’Ivoire) où elles seront vendues.          
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune avec ce troisième prêt un bénéfice moyen de 40.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utiliser pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir  aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités respectives.
texts.en:
Specialized in the commerce of various goods, such as Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), 'moins riche' damasks (highly prized fabrics in Africa), shoes, wallets, firewood, sugar, milk, spaghetti, and embroidered fabrics, the five women of the group Jigignouma live in large traditional families in Sanoubougou II, the downtown area of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). They are married and average 31 years of age and four children. The women of this group, of the association Soleil de Sanoubougou II, are on their third solidarity loan (group loan) with Soro Yiriwaso. All of the preceding loans have been repaid.
