They are requesting this loan to be able to buy: 1 sack of sugar, 3 boxes of milk, 1 box of spaghetti, 3 boxes of soap, 3 lengths of embroidered fabrics, 2 lengths of damask, 3 lengths of Wax pagnes, 1 ten-tonne truckload of firewood, 10 pairs of shoes, and 10 wallets. The cities of Bobo Dioulasso in Burkina Faso and Bamako and Sikasso in Mali are the principal sources of supplies for these women, who sell their merchandise at the marketplace of the city of Sikasso (and sometimes door-to-door in the districts) either wholesale or retail, cash and credit accepted. Some women send their merchandise to Abidjan (Republic of Côte d'Ivoire), where they are sold. With this third loan, they each hope to realize an average profit of 40,000 francs CFA per month, which will be used to cover the loan interest, provide for their families, and to invest the remainder in their respective businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy different goods (Was pagnes, damask, shoes, wallets, firewood, sugar, milk, spaghetti, embroidered fabrics

loans.name: Lai

texts.en: Lai M. lives in Koh Nhae Village in the Takeo Province.  Lai is 28 years old and the mother of two children. Her husband, San Both (both pictured), is a taxi driver who makes a small income to help support his family. She is a farmer who owns a small plot of land and cultivates rice for a living. Although she and her husband have different businesses, they still cannot support their family well. In order to improve their living conditions, Lai is asking for a loan to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en:
Bridget I. sells provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs. She is 40 years old and married with four children. She started her business with support from LAPO Microfinance and it business has been of immerse help to her family.

In order to increase her sales, Bridget needs a loan for N50,000 to purchase more drinks, foodstuffs, and provisions to sell. She is indeed grateful to Kiva lenders and LAPO Microfinance for all their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Deurng

texts.en: Deurng P. is 32 is married and is a mother of five children. Two of her children are construction workers, two are in school, and the youngest one is two years old. She and her husband, Pho Siev, live in the Tasoam Village in Takeo Province. Deurng is a farmer who earns a minimal revenue from her small plot of land. Even though Deurng and her husband have different businesses, their household is in poor condition and the house they live in is in bad condition. Deurng is asking for a loan to help build a new house for her family.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to add to her saving to build a new house for her family.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace O. is 38 years old and married with four children. She sells drinks, provisions, and foodstuffs retail to her customers.

Grace needs a loan for N52,000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Sponsa

texts.en:
Sponsa H., 41 years old, is from Dar es Salaam. She is married and has a child who is 14 years old. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting a 13-year-old girl who has lost her real parents.  
Sponsa earns income growing vegetables and selling them in the market. At present, she needs a loan of US$250 to be able to purchase an irrigation machine in order to increase the productivity and output of her vegetable garden. Sponsa is thankful to everyone for supporting her.

ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Purchase of an irrigation machine

loans.name: Sy – Sikasso – 00095 Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Jiguisèmè (composé de 4 femmes toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans et de 4 enfants vivent dans le village Kafela  situé à  20km de la ville de Sikasso(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali) dans des foyers polygames avec leur maris, des coépouses, les enfants et autres parents.
Uni par des liens de parenté, ce groupe fait généralement l’achat et la vente du charbon de bois et la préparation et vente de la bouillie de mil. Après avoir correctement remboursé tous les prêts précédents, elles sont à leur douzième prêt qui sera utilisé pour acheter,  75 sacs de charbon de bois, 30 sacs de mil et 10 sacs de sucre. Les graines de mil sont pilés, vannés et mis dans de l’eau chaude pour obtenir de la bouillie. Cette opération dure en moyenne une vingtaine de minutes.
Les graines de céréales sont achtés auprès des producteurs de céréales des villages aux alentours de la ville. Pour ce qui est du charbon les achats se font auprès des paysans ayant une autorisation de coupe de bois. Les articles ainsi achétés sont achéminés à Sikasso les jours de foire pour les revendre au comptant, en gros et en détail à une clientèle composée de revendeurs de Sikasso ou de Bamako.
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune avec ce prêt un bénéfice moyen de 15.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour  subvenir aux besoins de la famille et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Jiguiseme group (composed of four married women) are, on average 42 years old, with four (4) children. They live in the village of Kafela, located 20 km from the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Repiblic of Mali) in polygamous households with their husbands, co-wives, children and other relatives.

United through family lines, the group mainly buys and sells charcoal and prepares and sells millet porridge. After having successfully repaid all their former loans, they are now making this twelfth loan to purchase 75 sacks of charcoal, 30 sacks of millet and 10 sacks of sugar. The millet grain is crushed, washed and heated in hot water to make porridge. This process takes about twenty minutes.

The cereal grain is purchased from cereal producers located in the villages that surround the city. As for the charcoal, it is purchased from farmers who are authorized to cut wood.The purchased items are brought to Sikasso on market days to be resold for cash, wholesale or retail, to a clientele made up of retailers from Sikasso or Bamako.

With this loan, they each hope to earn a monthly profit of about 15,000 francs CFA, which would be used to meet the needs of their families and invest the remainder in their business activities.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal, millet and sugar

loans.name: Lorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Lorn M. lives in Koh Nhae Village in Takeo Province. She is 35 years old and the mother of five children. Four of her children attend the local school while the youngest, at three years old, is too young for work or study. She is a farmer who cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Sao Phat, helps her in their rice plantation.

However with only one business, it is hard for them to support their family well. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Lorn M. decided to ask for a loan to buy a breeding cow. She hopes to increase their income by selling bred cows in addition to rice.

loans.use: To purchase a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Neng

texts.en: Mrs. Neng T. lives in Ba Khong Khang Kiet Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer and owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice to make a living. A 46- year old widow, her only child helps support the family by selling chickens. Even though they both have jobs, they do not earn enough income to support themselves. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Neng T. decided to ask for a loan to buy a breeding cow. She hopes to increase their income by selling bred cows in addition to rice.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 45-year-old Fatuma I. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with 4 children, between the ages of 14 and 20.

Fatuma has been running a mama lishe since 2007. A mama lishe (local restaurant or café) in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches. The food is all-local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces.

Fatuma works at the business for 9 to 12 hours a day, 6 days a week. She is requesting a loan of $250 in order to purchase ingredients for the food that she serves at her mama lishe such as chai (tea), vitafunwa (slightly sweetened poofy pancakes made of rice flour that is deep fried and are to die for!!), and supu ya kongoro (beef soup). Fatuma thanks you for her support!

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for the food that she serves at her mama lishe

loans.name: Loveth

texts.en:
Loveth A. is a tailor. She is 35 years old and married with five children. She sews clothing of various styles for people in her community.

Loveth would like to add to her sewing business by also selling second-hand clothes. She says that this additional business will enable her make more profits. She needs the loan for N70,000 to purchase more second-hand clothes to sell. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand clothes to sell.

loans.name: Sareth

texts.en: Mrs. Sareth N. lives in Ang Korkir Village in Takeo Province. She is 39 years old and the mother of three children. Two of her children attend the local school while the youngest one, at age two,  is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Long Poy, is a motorbike taxi driver who earns $3 a day. This income is too small to support their family, so Mrs. Sareth N. sells vegetables in the local market. Her business is going well, and she would like to expand it. As such, she’s requesting a loan to increase her inventory by buying different kinds of vegetables to sell in order to meet her customers’ demands.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Sindiya (Cordialité) Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre (4) femmes du groupe Sindiya toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 31 ans et 04 enfants, vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier Médine de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Ces femmes ont comme principales activités l’achat et de vente de pomme de terre, d’orange et du bois de chauffe. Dans la recherche de ressources financières complémentaires, ce groupe a décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel il est à son premier prêt solidaire (prêt du groupe). 
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter, 1 chargement de camion benne en bois de chauffe, 1 chargement de charette en orange et 5 caisses de pomme de terre dans les villages environnants de Sikasso auprès de producteurs. Les ventes se font au marché où elles ont chacune une place, en détail, au comptant et à crédit avec une clientèle composée généralement des femmes et surtout des forains.     
Avec ce premier prêt, elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 20.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
The four women of the Sindiya group are all married with an average age of 31 and, on average, 4 children. They live in big extended traditional families in the Médine neighborhood of the town of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

As principal businesses, these women buy and sell potatoes, oranges, and firewood. As they were searching for additional financial resources, the group decided to join the loan program of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom they are on their first solidarity loan (group loan).

With this loan they intend to by 1 pick-up truckload of firewood, 1 wagonload of oranges, and 5 crates of potatoes in the villages surrounding Sikasso from the farmers. They sell in the market where each of them has a stall, retail, for cash or on credit, to a clientele generally composed of women and especially of merchants who come on market days from the big towns to buy goods for re-sale.

With this first loan they each hope to make an average monthly profit of 20,000 F CFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan and to help support their families.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy various articles: pototoes, oranges and firewood for re-sale

loans.name: Naila

texts.en:
Naila was born in 1966. She and her husband (who is shown in the picture) have two children. Naila is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, settled in Fuzuli region, Dilagarda village.

This family has been in clothing sales business for five years. Now they need a loan of 800 AZN (US$1,000) to buy clothes for improving their clothing sales business.

loans.use: To buy additional inventory for clothing business.

loans.name: Loveline

texts.en:
Loveline O. is 43 years old and married with six children. She lives in Benin City in Edo State, Nigeria. She needs a loan in the amount of N70,000. She will use the loan to purchase more clothing and jewelry to stock her shop as the festive season is fast approaching.

She says thank you to Kiva lenders and LAPO Microfinance. She says the Lord will continuously bless you.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and jewelries to sell

loans.name: Queen

texts.en: Queen O. is 30 years old and married with no children. She sells drinks and provisions. With the help of LAPO Microfinance she added the sale of lubricants, like engine and hydraulic oil. The demand for her lubricants is high. She needs a loan in the amount of N70,000 to purchase more engine oil to sell. She is very grateful to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more engine oil to sell.

loans.name: Bilquis Aziz Group

texts.en:
Bilquis baji is the wife of Mr. A. and resides in the city of Pakpattan, Pakistan. Pakpattan city is famous for its shrine of great Punjabi Sufi poet, Babar Fareed Ganj Shakkar. She has been living in this city for the past 10 years. She is the mother of two sons, both of whom are auto-rickshaw drivers (the local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Bilquis baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy another rickshaw for her eldest son, so that he able to increase his profits as a transit driver.

This is a group loan, and she is joined in her request by four other members. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in their own business. Kaneez baji wants a loan to buy a mirror and chair for her beauty salon. Zafran baji also wants a loan to buy a rickshaw. Mukhtayar baji wants a loan to buy tools for her vehicle repair workshop. Saima baji wants a loan to buy cigarettes for her cigarette selling business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a rickshaw

loans.name: Sara

texts.en:
Mrs. Sara N. was born in 1968 and lives in Trapeang Svay Village in Takeo Province. She is 40 years old and the mother of five children: one of her sons is a construction worker, another is a monk, two others attend the local school, and her youngest, at one year old, is too young to work or study.

Mrs. Sara N. is a farmer, and she cultivates rice on a small plot of land to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Ngaet Ork, is a construction worker who earns $2 a day. Despite their both having jobs, this is not enough money to support their family.  In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Sara N. decided to ask for a loan to buy a breeding cow. She hopes to increase their income by selling bred cows in addition to rice.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Chin

texts.en: Mr. Chin C. is a 34-year-old rice farmer who occasionally also buys beans wholesale to resell to people who live in his area. His wife, Mrs. Pock Yem, is 35 years old and makes a living by farming and raising pigs. They live in Speu Commune, Kompong Cham Province and have four children, all of whom attend school. Chin needs a $1,000 loan to buy more beans to store and resell, and also to buy food for the family's pigs. The loan will increase their income and allow them to buy more food for their children.

loans.use: to buy more beans to store and resell

loans.name: Soutoura (Confidentialité) Group

texts.fr:
Les sept (7) femmes du groupe Soutoura sont toutes mariées et ont en moyenne 34 ans et  04 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies à Sanoubougou I de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens d’amitié et de voisinage.  Leurs principales activités sont entre autres l’achat, la transformation des dechets des raffineries d’huile en savons,  et l’achat  vente des  pagnes wax (tissus très prisés en Afrique) ,d’arachide,  de mil et  de gomme.
Les savons traditionnels sont fabriqués à base des déchets d’huile de coton de potasses. 
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, ce groupe décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son 2ème prêt solidaire (prêt du groupe) et il s’est bien comporté dans les remboursements du prêt précédent.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, les membres du groupe comptent acheter, 2 bariques de dechet de cotons, 2 sacs de potasse, 22 pièces pagne wax, des habits pour d’enfants, 5 sacs de mil, 1 sac de sucre et 3 sacs de gomme henis. La ville de Bobo Dioulasso(du Burkina Faso), et les villes de Bamako et Sikasso sont leurs principales sources d’approvisionnement  de ce groupe de femmes.
Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Sikasso, à domicile et de façon ambulante en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée généralement des femmes. 
Avec ce prêt, elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 40.000 FCFA par mois qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
The seven women of the group Soutoura are all married and average 34 years of age and four children. They live in large extended traditional families in Sanoubougou I of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know one another through ties of friendship and community. Their principal work includes buying and transforming the waste oil from refineries into soaps, and it also includes buying and selling Wax pagnes (highly prized cloth in Africa), peanuts, millet, and gum. Traditional soaps are made with waste cotton oil and potash.

In order to satisfy a customer base that continues to grow, this group decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which it is on its second solidarity loan (group loan). And the group performed well in repaying the preceding loan.

With this new loan, the members of the group intend to buy: 2 barrels of cotton waste, 2 sacks of potash, 22 lengths of Wax pagnes, clothing for children, 5 sacks of millet, 1 sack of sugar, and 3 sacks of 'henis' gum. The city of Bobo Dioulasso (of Burkina Faso) and the cities of Bamako et Sikasso are their principal sources of supplies. The merchandise is sold at the Sikasso marketplace, out of homes, and door-to-door at the retail level, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed general of women.

With this loan, they each envision realizing an average profit of 40,000 francs CFA per month that will be use to cover the loan interest and to support their families.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy different goods (waste cotton oil, Wax pagnes, peanuts, millet, sugar, children's clothing, and gum)

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Blessing A. is 28 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. Blessing sells provisions and hydraulic fluids. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more engine oil to sell. She says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more engine oil and hydraulic fluids to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Ros Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is intended for ten people living in Poun Village in Kampong Cham. All of the members will use the loan for different purposes, but the members have selected Mr. S. R. as their village bank president. He is 40 years old and the father of four children, three of whom attend the local school. He is a pig breeder who is currentL. raising two pigs. As his pigs have gotten bigger and bigger however, he no longer has enough money to buy enough pig food. His wife, Mrs. Ung Ursim, is employed in garment factory, and her small salary also helps support the household, but it is not enough. As sU., Mr. S. R. would like to use the loan to buy more pig food for his breeding business.

This is village bank loan consists of end-of-term loans, so all the members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financialL. able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of onL. 0.09%, and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy pig food

loans.name: Edosa

texts.en:
Edosa I. sells provisions, foodstuffs and drinks. She lives in Benin City in Edo State, Nigeria. She is 40 years old and has five children. Her husband is a retired civil servant.

Edosa sells provisions like toothpaste, bathing soap, and detergent. She needs a loan in the amount of N52,000 to purchase more provisions, foodstuffs, and drinks to sell. She says that God will continuously bless Kiva lenders and LAPO Microfinance for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Nasreen M. Nazir Group

texts.en:
Nasreen baji is the widow of M. N. and lives in the city of Pakpattan, Pakistan. Pakpattan city is famous for its shrine of great Punjabi Sufi poet, Baba Fareed Ganj Shakkar. She has been living in this city for the past 10 years. She is the mother of five children: three sons and two daughters. Her eldest son has a juice stand. Her second son has a salon, and her youngest son is not currently employed. Both of her daughters are in school, in the 5th standard. Nasreen baji sells clothing, and she has been in this business for the past two years. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a second loan to buy more clothing to expand her business.

This is a group loan, and she is joined in her request by three other members. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in their own business. Zahida baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine to sew clothing to sell. Razia baji also wants a loan to buy more clothing to sell, and Shaheen baji wants a loan to buy spare motorbike parts to sell. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy A. sells drinks and beverages. She has been in this business for the past 2 years. Her store is located along Okhoro road in Benin City. This is a busy area in Benin City. She is the lady standing in the middle in the picture. She has 2 salesgirls who assist her with the sale of drinks.

Mercy hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She needs the loan amount of N90,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She is 36 years old and married with 3 children. She is grateful to Kiva lenders and to LAPO MICROFINANCE for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Sengthaiy

texts.en:
Mrs. Sengthaiy M. lives in Prey Pdeak village in Kampong Speu Province. She is 41 years old and the mother of six children. One of her children works in a garment factory while the rest attend the local school.

She and her husband, Mr. Koe Srey, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they cultivate rice to earn a living. However this work is not enough to support their family. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Sengthaiy M. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband so that he may begin a motorbike taxi business. She hopes with this new profession, her husband can make more money to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to start a taxi business.

loans.name: Rahma

texts.en:
Jambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 26-year-old Rahma B. from Dar es Salaam. She is single with 1 dependent, Salma, who is 8 years old and was an orphan. Rahma has been running 2 businesses, a charcoal business and a cloth shop, since March 2008.

At her mkaa (charcoal) business, she sells charcoal, which are small, black pieces of dry earth that are used by many Tanzanians as a fuel to cook their daily meals. Women cook food in small coal pots, in which they arrange charcoal, and add either paper, dry grass, old plastic bags, or kerosene in order to light them. Because there is such a high demand for charcoal across the country, being a charcoal seller is quite lucrative!

In addition, she has established a shop that sells traditional clothing worn by Tanzanian women, called kanga and vitenge. The kanga is a piece of printed cotton fabric often with a border along all 4 sides. It is printed using the silkscreen method with its pattern in frames. Kitenge (the Swahili plural is vitenge) is a cotton fabric with wax print, printed by using rotary printing machines. Kitenge is a communicating textile--the various colors, patterns, writings, and symbols represent moods, feelings, cultures, and traditions of native African people.

She splits her time between both business working 1-4 hours a day, 7 days a week at each business. She is requesting a loan of $250 in order to purchase additional inventory in bulk. Rahma thanks you in advance for your support!

loans.use: To purchase inventory in bulk

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther T. is 34 years old and married with four children. Esther has a shop where she sells baby things, like flasks, feeding bottles, and clothes. Her customers are mostly pregnant women and breast-feeding mothers.

The demands for her goods are high and she needs a loan in the amount of N71,000 to purchase more baby things to sell. She hopes to also support her husband and children with the profit she makes from her sales. She says thank you to all the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more baby things to sell.

loans.name: Danaya (La Confiance) Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre (4) femmes du groupe Danaya (toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 49 ans et 02 enfants vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies à Médine un des quartiers de la ville Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali) 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens d’amitié et de voisinage.  Leurs principales activités sont entre autres l’achat et la vente des pommes de terre, des pagnes wax et fancy(imprimés sur place au Mali par la Comatex) et la restauration.
Ce groupe travaille avec l’institution Soro Yiriwaso depuis  maintenant 4 et est à son sixième prêt solidaire. Elles comptent utiltiser ce prêt pour acheter, 10 sacs de pomme de terre, 34 pièces de pagnes, 2 sacs de riz et 2 bidons d’huile d’arachide. Elles s’approvisionnent (en matières premières pour la restauration)  au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso. Quant aux pagnes elles s’y ravitaillent sur commande auprès de grossistes de Bamako(capitale de la republique du Mali).
Les ventes sont effectués au marché, à domicile et de façon ambulante en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée généralement des femmes et des jeunes gens.
texts.en:
The four women of the group Danaya are all married and average 49 years of age and two children. They live in traditional extended familes in Médine, one of the districts of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know one another through ties of friendship and community. Their principal work includes catering and commerce in potatoes and 'wax' and 'fancy' grades of pagnes (colorful West African cloth) that are printed locally in Mali by Comatex.

For four years now, this group has been working with the institution Soro Yiriwaso and is on its sixth solidarity loan. The group intends to utilize this loan to buy: 10 sacks of potatoes, 34 lengths of pagnes, 2 sacks of rice, and 2 drums of peanut oil.

The members of the group get their supplies (of raw ingredients for catering) at the grand marketplace in the city of Sikasso. As for the pagnes, they are restocked by custom order from the wholesalers of Bamako (capital of Mali).

The sales are made at the marketplace, out of homes, and door-to-door at the retail level, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed generally of women and youngsters.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy different goods:  pagnes, rice peanut oil, and potatoes

loans.name: Abies

texts.en: Abies E. is a retired civil servant. She sells plastics, provisions, drinks and foodstuffs. Abies is a hardworking woman and she is determined to excel in her business. She needs the loan amount of N40,000 to purchase more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She is 59 years old and married with 3 children. She is indeed grateful to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella M. sells female wrappers (sarongs) and children's clothes. She is 40 years old and married with four children. Her youngest child is in Primary 4 at a public school.

Stella buys the wrappers from Onitsha market and sells them to people in her neighborhood. She had a shop at Uselu market but a fire burned the market. She lost most of her wrappers and the shop. She relocated back to her house and now sells her wrappers from home.

Stella hopes for a loan in the amount of N51,000 to use to rent a new shop at the market and to purchase more wrappers for sale. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more female wrappers (sarongs) to sell.

loans.name: Dilish

texts.en:
Dilish was born in 1966. She and her husband, who is shown in the photo, have two children. Dilish is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, settled in Fuzuli region, Bala Bahmanli village.

Dilish and her husband started sheep breeding business six years ago. Now this family needs a loan of 800 AZN (US$1,000) to buy ten sheep.

loans.use: To buy ten sheep

loans.name: Radhia

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 45-year-old Radhia I. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with 3 children, between the ages of 9 and 23. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting 2 dependents because they are orphans. Radhia has been running a mama lishe since 2000.

A mama lishe (local restaurant or café) in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough made from maize flour), and plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces.

She works at the business 9 to 12 hours a day, 7 days a week. She is requesting a loan of $550 in order to expand her business by purchasing ingredients in bulk and making additional menu items. Radhia thanks you for her support!

loans.use: To purchase ingredients

loans.name: Dementria

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 28-year-old Dementria S. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with 1 child who is 9. Dementria has been running a grocery store since 2005.

A Tanzanian grocery store is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, bottled water, tomatoes, soda, chili, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

Dementria works at the business 9 to 12 hours a day and is assisted by her husband. She is requesting a loan of $550 in order to keep up the maintenance of her business as well as expand her business.

Dementria thanks you for her support!

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Aissatou P.

texts.fr: Aissatou P D., 32 ans, mariée, 06 enfants  en charge est membre du banc villageois de Sinthiang Coundara depuis 5 ans et demi. Elle veut un prêt pour acheter des arachides qu’elle décortique et transforme en pâte d’arachide pour vendre. Ses revenus lui permettent de participer aux dépenses familiales. Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
texts.en:
Aissatou P. D., 32, married and raising 6 children, has been a member of the village bank of Sinthiang Coundara for 5 and a half years. She wants a loan to buy peanuts which she shells and transforms into peanut butter for sale. Her income allows her to help support her family. The loan that she is requesting will be reimbursed at the end of 6 months in one single repayment.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of peanuts, dead wood, buckets, and payment of labor

loans.name: Elmira

texts.en:
Elmira is single (her brother is shown in the photo). She was born in 1966. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, settled in Fuzuli region Kayidish village, which is built for IDPs.

Four years ago Elmira, with her brother, started a sheep breeding business. Now they need a loan of 800 AZN (US$1,000) to buy ten sheep.

loans.use: To buy ten sheep

loans.name: Mariama Kesso

texts.fr: Mariama Kesso D., 21 ans, mariée, 01 enfant en charge est membre du banc villageois de Sinthiang Coundara depuis 4 ans. Elle veut un prêt pour acheter des arachides qu’elle décortique et transforme en pâte d’arachide pour vendre. Elle a une bonne expérience et veut renforcer son activité. Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
texts.en:
Mariama Kesso D., age 21, is married and has one child. She has been a member of the village loan group Sinthiang Coundara for four years. She wants a loan to make peanut butter to sell. She has good experience and wants to bolster her business. The loan she is requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanuts, firewoods, buckets and to hire help

loans.name: Atawa

texts.fr: Atawa K.  est âgée de 43ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle est revendeuse de draps et de serviettes à wome, un village situé au nord-ouest de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Pour mieux satisfaire ses clients, Atawa souhaite relancer son activité par l’achat de nouveaux articles ; ce qui lui permettra d’augmenter ses ventes et tirer plus de profits pour mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille
texts.en:
Atawa K. is 43 years old, married, and the mother of four. She is a retailer of sheets and napkins in Wome, a village located northwest of Lomé, the Togolese capital. To satisfy her customers better, Atawa wishes to reinvigorate her business by buying new goods, which will enable her to increase her sales and to derive more profit in order to provide for her family better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheets and napkins to sell

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr: Kokou D. est un conducteur de taxi moto depuis 3 ans. Il habite à wome, un village situé à environ 130 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Sa moto faisant objet de réparations régulières, ce qui lui fait dépenser beaucoup, Kokou souhaite par ce crédit acheter une nouvelle moto pour relancer son activité. Cette occasion lui permettra faire plus d’économie pour mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille
texts.en:
Kokou D. has been a motorbike taxi driver for three years. He lives in Wome, a village situated about 80 miles from Lomé, which is the capital of Togo. Due to the fact that his motorbike undergoes constant repairs, which have cost him a lot of money, Kokou wishes to buy a new motorbike using this loan so he can relaunch his business. This opportunity will allow him to make more money so he will be in a better position to provide for his family.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike

loans.name: Elshan

texts.en:
Elshan was born in 1970. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, settled in Fuzuli region Kayidish village, which is built for IDPs. He is married and has two children.

Elshan has three years of experience in fruits and vegetables sales. Now he needs a loan of 800 AZN (US$1,000) to buy more fruits and vegetables for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine O. is 39 years old and married with 4 children. She is a hair stylist. She makes lovely hairstyles for her customers. The frequent power outages have affected her business negatively. She is losing her customers to competitors who have generators.

Josephine needs a loan in the amount of N52,000 to purchase a generator that will help her to retain her customers. She also wants to buy more hair extensions to sell. This, she says, will enable her to retain her customers. She is grateful to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy a generator and hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia I. lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is 38 years old and married with 3 children. She is a computer operator but due to unemployment, she began selling drinks and provisions. She has been in this business for a long time. She needs the loan amount of N52,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says this will help her to maximize her profit. She says a big thank you to all Kiva lenders and to LAPO MICROFINANCE for their financial and technical support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria I. owns a large room where she sells and rent VCDs (video compact discs), clothes, shoes, and bags. She also makes phone calls for customers and is a hair stylist.

Victoria is 60 years old and has four children. As a widow, her business has been her major source of income. She needs a loan in the amount of N140,000 to purchase more clothes, bags, and shoes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes, bags, and shoes to sell.

loans.name: Efe

texts.en:
Efe O. is a hairstylist and also sells baby care products. She is 33 years old with three children and lives in Benin City in Edo State, Nigeria.

Efe needs a loan in the amount of N52,000 to buy more baby care products to sell. Efe is a hardworking woman and she hopes to retain her customers. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more baby care products to sell.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet A. is 32 years old and single. She lives Benin City in Edo State, Nigeria, where she owns a store in which she sells wrappers (sarongs).

She buys her goods in small quantities from Onitsha and Lagos. She needs a loan amount of N52,000 to purchase more wrappers to sell. The increased inventory will help boost her business. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell.

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William O. is 35 years old and married with four children. He is a furniture maker who makes furniture for both office and home use. The demand for his furniture is high and he needs a loan in the amount of N52,000 to purchase more wood in bulk for his furniture business.

He says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support and LAPO Microfinance for their business training.

loans.use: To purchase more wood for furniture making.

loans.name: Zokhra

texts.en:
Zokhra has been in cafe business for ten years. She is a mother of three children. This woman is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, settled in Fuzuli region, Bala Bahmanli village. She was born in 1955.

Now, Zokhra needs a loan of 800 AZN (US$1,000) to buy kitchen appliances for her cafe.

loans.use: To buy kitchen appliances for her cafe.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina S. is 37 years old. She is married and the mother of four kids. Currently, the kids are in school. Amina loves selling goods, the business through which she makes money to support her family. She has been selling onions and beans for ten years to support her family. Onion is one of the popular food spices which add flavor to sauces and soups. Beans are used in the preparation of many local foods like ‘red-red’, beans sauce and kebab. The sale of these commodities has created job opportunities for many women like Amina. She takes delivery of stock from the local farmers who provide her with direct supply, and retails to her customers. This enables her to avoid middlemen who buy from the farmers and resell to her at higher prices. 

With this loan, she wants to buy bulk of onions and beans to serve her customers. She hopes that the loan will enable her to make more savings to support her kids in school. Amina is a member of a borrowing group called Good Shepherd Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans.

loans.use: To purchase bulk of onions and beans.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy E. sells drinks. She buys the drinks from distributors in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is happy because the festive season is approaching and the demands for her drinks will increase. She is requesting the loan amount of N52,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She is 58 years old and married with seven children. She and her family live in Benin City. She says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more crates drinks to sell

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy O. owns a boutique where she sells clothes and shoes. She is 38 years old and married with 2 children. Her children are in primary schools in Benin City. She purchases her clothes and shoes from Lagos and Onitsha market to sell Benin City. She needs the loan amount of N41,000 to purchase more clothes and shoes to sell. She says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Balikyewunya 2 Women's Group

texts.en: Margaret B. is the mother of three school-going children and is also responsible for several orphans.  She works as the treasurer of Balikyewunya Women's Group, but is primarily a farmer of bananas, maize, beans, and cassava, which she grows and sells in her local market.  Although Margaret has been farming for many years, she has recently started selling clothes as well.  Both of these businesses complement each other and provide Margaret with a comfortable income.  However, her colleagues in Balikyewunya Women's Group have entrepreneurial spirits and want to develop their own businesses as well.  Therefore, as the treasurer, Margaret is requesting a loan of $4800, which will be used to purchase large quantities of clothes for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Nneka

texts.en: Nneka A. lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is 40 years old and married with 6 children. Her husband is a security guard. She sells pure water and drinks. Nneka also sells foodstuffs in her store. She needs the loan amount of N41,000 to purchase more drinks and pure water to sell. She says this loan will enable her to stock her store with more drinks. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and pure water to  sell

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina K. sells fresh eggs in the local market of Ashaiman, a suburb of Tema where she lives with her family. She is 28 years and is married, with a child who is currently in school. She travels to the smaller communities of Tema to purchase the eggs directly from the poultry farmers. This enables her to avoid middlemen who buy and then resell to traders at a higher price. Regina does not have adequate working capital to support her trade. She sometimes obtains her supplies on credit and makes payment after sales and thus incurs additional charges.  

With the loan, she wants to purchase more fresh eggs in bulk to serve her customers. She hopes to increase her profit margin to enable her to save more money to support her family, and especially for her child's education. Regina is a member of a borrowing group called “So mu yie” (meaning, handle with care) Trust Group. In this group, members assist one another to provide support in handling the repayment of the loan.

loans.use: To purchase fresh eggs in bulk for resale

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose A. is 52 years old and married with six children. She lives in Benin City in Edo State, Nigeria, where she sells clothes. She is happy because the festive season is fast approaching and the demand for her clothes will be high.

She is requesting a loan in the amount of N52,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience E. is 53 years old, married, and has 5 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria, She makes her living selling beef at Ekiuwa market.  She purchases the beef from the local abattoir.

She is requesting a loan of 52,000, US$450, to purchase more beef to sell. She is indeed very grateful to all kiva lenders and LAPO MICROFINANCE for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more beef to sell

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice K. is an executive member of Ntinda Kafene Women's Group.  She manages a retail shop in her town's trading center that sells sugar, soap, maize flour, baking flour, cooking oil, and many other household staples.  Beatrice's shop is know for always being open, as well as being very clean, organized, and tidy.  Therefore, she has many loyal customers.  In order to restock her shop and increase the variety of products she offers, however, Beatrice is requesting a loan of $1000.

loans.use: To restock supplies and diversify products offered.

loans.name: Tarana

texts.en:
Tarana and her husband (who is pictured) have two children. Tarana is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, settled in Fuzuli region, Karimbayli village. Tarana was born in 1976.

Tarana's husband has been making doors and windows for four years. Now they need a loan of 800 AZN (US$1,000) for buying necessary materials for making doors and windows.

loans.use: To buy the necessary materials for making doors and windows.

loans.name: Guillermina

texts.es:
Guillermina es socia del Banco Comunal San Gabriel.
Guillermina es casada, tiene 63 años y 3 hijos D. 40, 38 y 32 años. Todos sus hijos  trabajan. 
Guillermina tiene su negocio D. crianza D. chanchos en el distrito D. Mala, Guillermina cría y venD. chanchos, ella viaja 3 veces al mes a Mala llevando la comida para sus animales, compra semanalmente 2 sacos D. comida, tiene personal en Mala que se encarga D. ver a sus animales .
Guillermina actualmente apoya a sus nietos , los está criando.
Guillermina necesita un préstamo D. 400 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra D. comida para los animales. 
Guillermina sueña con seguir creciendo en su negocio.
texts.en:
Guillermina is a member of the San Gabriel Community Bank. She is married, 63 years old and mother of three children, ages 40, 38 and 32, all of whom work for a living. Guillermina's business raises pigs in the district of Mala, Peru. She raises the pigs and then sells them. She travels three times a month to Mala to take feed to her animals; she buys two sacks of feed a week. She has workers in Mala in charge of watching her livestock. Guillermina currently is raising her grandchildren. She's requesting a loan of 400 soles, which she will invest in the purchase of feed for her animals. Her dream is to continue growing her business.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy feed for her animals

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en:
Christiana E. is 49 years old and she is married with 7 children. Christiana sells tailoring materials at New Benin market in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.  Christiana is a hardworking woman and has one sewing machine that she uses to sew clothes for her customers. She makes lovely Nigerian designs for her customers, who are mostly women and children. 

Christiana needs the loan amount of N70,000, US$600, to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support and LAPO MICROFINANCE for their business training.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Holdrich

texts.es:
Holdrich tiene un radio taxi en la empresa Tramix de la zona Sur, es soltero y no tiene hijos .Vive en el Sector de El Rosal de la Zona Sur en la ciudad de La Paz.
El crédito será destinado para el mantenimiento completo de su vehiculo (chaperia, compra de llantas y tapizado de asientos)
Es la segunda vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, su historial lo califica como cliente 1 es decir con cumplimiento bueno en el pago de sus cuotas, por lo que le permite acceder a este crédito ya que se gano la confianza financiera.
texts.en:
Holdrich has a radio taxi with the company Tramix in the south area of the city. He is single and he doesn't have children. He lives in the El Rosal neighborhood in the south area of the city of La Paz. The loan will be used to do a complete car maintenance of his vehicle (door locks, tires, and new tapestry for the car seats). This is the second time that he has requested a loan with Impro. His records show that he qualifies as client "1" , meaning he makes his payments on time, therefore he can have access to this loan since he has a good financial history.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Maintenance for his taxi.

loans.name: Dios Con Nosotros Group

texts.en:
"Dios con nosotros" is a large group of Esperanza borrowers. In this group, ten members are hoping to receive a loan. This group has all been very successful and some are receiving their sixth loan!

Lorenza is the group representative and chosen leader, and for good reason. Lorenza is a very hard worker and a very responsible person. She is the mother of two young children and does everything with her children in mind. She owns a small store and hopes to keep increasing business. She is a great success story because she went from having no income to owning her own small store. She really feels like her future is very bright and is excited that she can provide for her children. This new loan is going to increase the size of her business and should help her a lot.

The whole group is excited about this new loan and the opportunity they are receiving!

On behalf of Lorenza, the group, and Esperanza International, thank you for your help!!!!!

loans.use: Buy products for sale

loans.name: Celina

texts.en:
Celina I. is 50 years old and she is a widow with 5 children. In this photo, Celina is standing with her third child, who is a graduate of the University of Benin. Celina is a caterer and she bakes cakes for social ceremonies. She also provides outdoor catering services to her customers. 

Celina needs the loan amount of N52,000, US$450, to purchase more catering materials like flour, sugar, and cooking pots. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders and LAPO MICROFINANCE. She says that God will continue to bless Kiva lenders because they are putting smiles on the people's faces.

loans.use: To purchase more catering materials for cooking and baking

loans.name: Dorah

texts.en: Dorah N. is an executive member of Kafene Women's Group and is a contractor with Coca-Cola.  She purchases large quantities of Coca-Cola products at subsidized prices and sells them at retail shops in Ntinda and at the surrounding trading centres.  Dorah has been working in this business for over eight years and has many established commercial relationships with her customers.  Each time she is able to purchase more Coca-Cola products upfront, her profit increases.  Therefore, in order to expand her business, Dorah is requesting a loan of $1000.

loans.use: To purchase more products for resale upfront.

loans.name: Ayeshetu

texts.en:
Ayeshetu A. is 45 years old. She is a wife and the mother of five children who are currently in school. Ayeshetu lives with her family in Ashaiman, a suburb of Tema in the Greater Accra region of Ghana. She is a food vendor and has been selling “waakye” for the past ten years. Waakye is a popular local dish made from cooked rice and beans, enjoyed with pepper sauce, macaroni and fish. It is sold in the mornings as breakfast. It is very tasty and satisfying and many Ghanaians enjoy waakye. 

With the loan, she intends to purchase more bags of rice, vegetable oil, beans, and macaroni in bulk to prepare delicious ‘waakye’ for her customers. She believes the loan will enable her to save more money to send her first son to medical school next year. She is a member of a borrowing group called “Marigo” (meaning, diligence) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee social collateral for one another in order to access loans, and they provide assistance to one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To purchase rice, vegetable oil, beans and macaroni in bulk.

loans.name: Suzan

texts.en: Suzan N. is an executive member of Ntinda Kafene Women's Group and has a business selling both groceries and cooked food from her house.  She has recently also added various rental options to her business to increase her income.  Because the sale of food is the core function of her business, Suzan is hoping to purchase more goods in bulk  and thereby lower her operating costs.  She has therefore applied for a loan of $1000, which will be a major first step in her ambitious plans to expand her businesses.

loans.use: To purchase food ingredients in bulk.

loans.name: Festus

texts.en:
Festus O. is 32 years old and is married with a child. He sells provisions such as toothpaste, beverages, bathing soaps, and detergent. Festus is a client of LAPO and his shop is at Oliha market in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. The strategic location of his store attracts many customers. 

Festus needs the loan amount of N70, 000, US$600, to purchase more provisions to sell. He hopes to retain his customers and says thank you to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Frank

texts.en:
Frank E. is 27 years old and is single. He sells electronics at New Benin market in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. He buys the electronics from Ontisha main market and sells them in Benin City. He opens his store at 7:30am and closes each day by 7:00pm. 

Frank needs the loan amount of N70,000, US$600, to purchase more electronics to sell. He says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more electronics to sell

loans.name: Eugene

texts.en:
Eugene O. is 27 years old and is single. He sells motorcycle spare parts at forestry road in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. He is a client of LAPO and is the leader of a lending group. 

Eugene buys the motorcycle parts from Onitsha main market and sells them in Benin City. The demand for his product is high. He needs the loan amount of N70,000, US$600, to buy more spare parts to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more motorcycle spare parts to sell

loans.name: Oliver

texts.en: Oliver U. is 30 years old and is single. He sells furniture materials at Eharkpen Street in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria.  Oliver opens his shop at 8am and closes by 7pm daily. He has one sales boy who assists him with sales in his shop. Oliver loves his business and is determined to excel in it. Oliver needs the loan amount of N70,000 (US$600) to purchase more furniture materials to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders and LAPO microfinance for their financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more furniture materials to sell

loans.name: El Sol Sale Para Todos Group

texts.en:
This group of nine individuals is from a larger group of 22, called "El Sol Sale Para Todos". They are all looking to receive a loan to either start a small business or increase the small business they started with an earlier loan.

Magaly is the group representative and chosen leader. She is a very hardworking woman, and she has a lot to work hard for. She is a single mother of four young children who all depend on her to provide for them. Before her first loan, she had no form of income and she and her children were barely getting by. She now has a small business selling food and hopes to increase the size of her business and generate more income. She dreams of living in her own house and being able to send her kids to college. She is ready to work for those dreams and believes this is the first step!

On behalf of Magaly, the group, and Esperanza International, thank you for your support!!!

loans.use: Products for food production

loans.name: Elshan

texts.en:
Elshan was born in 1978. He is a single young man, an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli town, settled in Fuzuli region, Horadiz village.

Elshin has been in cattle breeding business for three years. Now he needs a loan of 800 AZN (US$1,000) to buy two calves.

loans.use: To buy two calves.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.es:
Gladys  vive junto a su esposo y sus dos pequeños hijos de 3 años y 2 meses.
 
Ellos constituyen una pareja joven que,  gracias a su trabajo adquirieron un  lote de terreno en una de las zonas periféricas de la cuidad en donde realiza mejoras para poder vivir con un poco de comodidad.

 Se dedica a la confección de pequeñas alfombras, y su esposo se dedica a la elaboración de mochilas y trabaja como portero de medio turno en una institución, de la ciudad de La Paz.

El crédito lo destinará en la adquisición de materiales de construcción para ampliar las habitaciones de su domicilio.
 
 
Es el segundo  crédito con Impro, y el segundo vía KIVA la evaluación realizada la califica para otorgarle el crédito.
texts.en:
Gladys lives with her husband and two small children, who are three and two years old, respectively. Gladys and her husband are a young couple, who acquired some land thanks to their hard work. Their land is in one of the peripheral zones of the city where they are making improvements so as to live more comfortably. Gladys sews small rugs, and her husband makes backpacks and works as a doorman in the city of La Paz. The loan will be used to buy construction materials to expand the bedrooms in their home. This is Gladys' second loan with Impro, and the second through Kiva, whose evaluation qualified her for a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction materials to expand two bedrooms in her house.

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina raises a 16-year-old daughter. She tries to provide her with everything she needs, which is why Marina works hard to keep up with financial challenges and keep her business running. Marina sells women’s clothing items in one of the busiest markets in Simferopol, Ukraine. The inventory she sells is very high quality. Even though her prices are a little higher than average, Marina has gained many loyal customers who keep coming back to buy clothes from her.  

Marina has been in business for about 20 years. The loans she has received and promptly repaid with Nadiya Ukraine have promoted consistent increase in her sales and profits. Currently, she has around 6,000 Grivnas of working capital. Her net profit is about 2,000 Grivnas every month. Marina has requested a loan for 5,000 Grivnas to help open a new vending kiosk and expand her trade. She is hoping that this loan will have a positive impact on her business profitability and help her further improve the economic and social situation of her family.

loans.use: Open a new vending facility

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
Mercedes es socia del Banco Comunal San Gabriel.
Mercedes es casada, tiene 47 años y 1 hijo de 9 años. Que  está en  la escuela.  
Mercedes tiene su negocio de venta de productos de belleza,  cosméticos Ebel, empezó hace 1 año apoyando a una señora a vender . Mercedes solo trabaja con los productos de Ebel.
Mercedes necesita un préstamo de 400 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de cosméticas Ebel para tener un stock.  
Mercedes sueña con tener un buen negocio propio y que su hija sea profesional.
texts.en:
Mercedes is a member of the San Gabriel Community Bank. She is married, 47 years old and the mother of a 9-year-old daughter, who is in school. She sells brand-name beauty products and cosmetics. She started a year ago helping a woman sell her products. Mercedes only works with Ebel brand products. She is requesting a loan of $150, which she will invest in the purchase of Ebel cosmetics to increase her stock. Mercedes' dream is to have her own prosperous business and for her daughter to be successful.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase Ebel brand cosmetics to increase her stock

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga lives with her mother and sister. She owns a small booth at the central market and sells women’s clothing, mostly terry cloth robes. Due to good marketing strategy--reasonable mark-up and renewed assortment--she is able to attract many clients. Her gross revenue is about 13,000 UAH per month. The net income is about 2,000 UAH. 

Olga has been working in this business for 12 years. At that time she just could not find any other job. Being a very responsible and honest person she was able to start and develop this business to provide for herself, her mother and her sister. 
 
Olga would like to get a loan for 5,000 UAH to buy more terry cloth robes and increase her sales. She hopes that increased sales activity will generate the funds they need to fix their house.

loans.use: Purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga lives with her mother and sister.  She owns a small booth at the central market and sells women’s clothing - terry cloth robes. Due to good marketing strategy – reasonable mark-up and renewed assortment– she is able to attract many clients. Her gross revenue is about 13,000 UAH per month. The income is about 2,000 UAH. 

Olga has been working in this business for 12 years. At that time she just could not find any other job. Being very responsible and honest person she was able to start and develop this business to provide for herself, her mother and her sister. 
 
Olga would like to get a loan for 5,000 UAH to buy more terry cloth robes and increase the sales. She hopes that increased sales activity will generate the funds they need to fix their house.

loans.use: purchase more goods

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es:
Nancy  vive en la calle “ A “  de la zona Villa Yunguyo en la ciudad de El Alto.
 
Vive junto a su sus hijos de 14, 13 y 9 años en tres habitaciones las cuales las tomo en anticretico, su esposo trabaja como chofer en el interior del país.

Ella se dedica al comercio de camas y colchas las cuales las vende a empleados de  diferentes oficinas de la ciudad, quienes le pagan en dos o tres cuotas.

El crédito lo destinara en la adquisición de mayor  mercadería para incrementar sus ingresos y ayudar a su esposo. 
 
Es el primer  crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada lo califica para otorgarle el crédito.
texts.en:
Nancy lives in the "A" street in the Villa Yunguyo neighborhood of the city of El Alto. She lives with her children who are 14, 13 and 9-year-old respectively in three rooms that she got as an antichretic (or land-pawn) creditor. Her husband works as driver in the province. She sells beds and bedspreads to employees of different offices in the city, who pay her in two or three quotas. The loan will be use to buy a bigger quantities of merchandise to be able to increase her income and help her husband. This is the first credit with Impro, the evaluation performed qualifies her to obtain the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy beds and bedspreads for her business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Bde Amistad Group

texts.en:
This is a group of five people hoping to receive another loan. Each person in this group has received loans in the past and have all paid back all the loan payments. Each member has had some success with their business and is now at the point where they want to expand and start generating more income.

Juana G. is the group representative and is a very dedicated mother to three children. She works as hard as she does because she wants a better life for her children. She says that her main goal is to get her children educated so they can get out of their poverty and live a better life. She has a small business selling used clothing in her area and hopes to one day have her own clothing store. She dreams of traveling and having her own house. This loan could be the start of getting her to those dreams and getting her children to college!

On behalf of Juana, the group, and Esperanza International, thank you for your support!!!

loans.use: Purchase clothing at low prices

loans.name: Elvis Jose

texts.es:
Elvis es socio del Banco Comunal San Gabriel.
Elvis tiene 28 años y 2 hijos de 4 y 1 año, el año que viene va a mandar a su primer hijo al jardín.   
Elvis tiene su negocio de venta de edredones, platos, cubiertos, y otras variedades, empezó hace medio año con este negocio, Elvis entrega su mercadería  a sus clientes a  crédito y el modo de cobranza es diario para algunos y semanal para otros, Elvis no tiene un puesto  fijo él recorre las calles en un triciclo mostrando su mercadería
Elvis necesita un préstamo de 400 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de edredones, platos y otros artículos , lo que le pidan sus clientes.  
Elvis sueña con que su negocio crezca y tener un puesto para  surtirlo de mercadería tener variedades.
texts.en:
Elvis is a member of the Communal Bank San Gabrial. Elvis is 28 years old and has 2 children, 4 and 1 years old, next year he is going to send his first son to school. Elvis has his business selling plates, silverware, and other various things. He started this business half a year ago. Elvis sells his merchandise to his customers on credit and the payments are daily for some and weekly for some. Elvis doesn't have a spot in the market so he goes around the streets on a tricycle showing his merchandise. Elvis needs a loan of 400 soles, money which wil be invested in the purchase of plates and other items, which his clients order from him. Elvis dreams that his business will grow and have a place to display his merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying merchandise

loans.name: Jamira

texts.en:
For the past two years, Jamira I. M. has been trading in the local market of Tema in Ghana. She is twenty seven years old, married and has a child who is currently in school. She is a food vendor who sells porridge and at the same time, is a busy petty trader who sells beans, groundnuts, millet, wheat, and soy beans. 

Jamira is convinced that her business can grow better with increased capital. She wants to use the loan to buy more of the products she trades and thus increase her inventory. She also hopes to use part of her proceeds to finance her child's education. She belongs to the community group called Saamu *Receiving* Trust Group. In this group, members assist one another by providing support in handling their loan repayments. Her picture was taken when she was visited during her group meeting.

loans.use: Increase inventory of beans, groundnuts, millet etc.

loans.name: Yenitt Saby

texts.es:
Yenitt es socia del Banco Comunal San Gabriel.
Yenitt tiene 36 años y 2 hijos de 15 y 3 años, el mayor está en el colegio
Yenitt tiene su negocio de venta de jugos, ella prepara y reparte los jugos que le piden. 
Yenitt necesita un préstamo de 400 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de insumos , utensilios,y otros cosas que le hagan falta  para colocarlos en un puesto de juguería que piensa alquilar. 
Yenitt sueña con construir su casa y alquiler cuartos.También quisiera tener un buen puesto en el mercado.
texts.en:
Yenitt is a member of the San Gabriel Community Bank. She is 36 years old and has two children, ages 15 and 3. The eldest is in high school. Yenitt sells juices that she prepares and delivers on order. She is requesting a loan of $150 to invest in the purchase of ingredients, utensils and other items she needs to set up a juice stand that she plans to rent. Her dream is to have her own home and rent out the rooms. She would also like to have a good post in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients, utensils and other items she needs to set up a juice stand that she plans to rent.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is married with six children and lives in Mbengwi, a rural town outside of Bamenda, Cameroon. She will invest her loan in her pig business and the cultivation of crops. She plans to invest her loan in increasing her number of pigs, fixing her pig stalls, and buying pig feed. She will contribute 150,000 CFA ($300 USD) of her savings towards her business plan.

This is Alice's fourth loan; she has been a member since 2004. This loan will help her pig business to succeed because she will be able to feed her pigs well, resulting in larger pigs to be sold for a greater profit. She will also be able to purchase healthy piglets with access to more capital. She plans to use the manure from her pigs both for her personal crops as well as to sell in the community.

With the profits from this loan, Alice will repair her home's broken roof. She will also pay her children's school fees and ensure that they are well prepared for school. She would like to purchase more piglets and continue to buy sufficient food for them with the rest of her profits. Her training in business management that she received from GHAPE will help her to invest this loan in the most efficient and productive manner.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To increase her number of pigs, fix her pig stalls, and buy pig feed

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana runs a small jeans and clothing sales business in the central market of Simferopol. She launched his business four years ago and has opened two vending facilities since then. Presently, Tatyana has about 30,000 Grivnas invested in business. Her monthly net income is about 8,000 Grivnas. 

Tatyana is requesting a loan of 4000 Grivnas to purchase seasonal inventory and increase her sales. She is hoping to see long-term consistent development of her venture. Tatyana used to work as a salesperson and realized how efficient this trade was. She is happy to be self-employed today, to make a profit and to generate enough savings to afford to buy separate (single-family) housing some day.

loans.use: Increase her seasonal inventory

loans.name: Rogger Kenny

texts.es:
Rogger es socio del Banco Comunal San Gabriel.
Rogger tiene 27 años y es soltero.
Rogger tiene su negocio de alquiler equipo de sonido y luces, empezó con este negocio hace 4 años. Rogger alquila en su mayoría semanalmente, y todos sus instrumentos de trabajo los tiene en su casa.
Rogger necesita un préstamo de 400 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de luces, reflectores. 
Rogger sueña con tener equipos de sonido para  alquilarlos para eventos y conciertos grandes.  Rogger  También quisiera comprar una consola y poner una discoteca.
texts.en:
Rogger is a member of the San Gabriel Community Bank. He is 27 years old and single. His business, which he started four years ago, rents out sound and lighting equipment. Rogger rents mostly by the week, and all his supplies are kept at his home. He is requesting a loan of $150 to invest in the purchase of lights and spotlights. His dream is to have sound equipment good enough to rent out for large events and concerts. He would also like to purchase a console table and set up a discotheque.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase lights and spotlights.

loans.name: Paz Y Esperanza Group

texts.en:
This is a group of 5 women who are looking to take out another loan. Each woman has taken out a previous loan, and all the women have been very faithful in making all their payments.

Anarelis is the group representative, and she was chosen because she is an great example of a hardworking woman, who is very diligent in all her payments. She has been very successful with her previous loans. She started a small business selling food in her area, and it has grown and grown. She is a single woman who hopes to have a family someday, but wants to be able to provide for her children before she has any. She thinks this new loan will help her business grow a lot, and so she is very excited about this opportunity!

On behalf of Anarelis, the group, and Esperanza International------ Thank you for your support!

loans.use: Buying products for her food business

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina is a small entrepreneur from Simferopol. She runs a business selling women’s shoes and boots in the central city marketplace. Galina has a serious business approach, focusing on client demand and modern fashion trends. She has been in this trade for 5 years. Presently, she has about 10,000 Grivnas in inventory. Her net profit is about 2,000 Grivnas.   

Galina is very enthusiastic about her venture. She has encouraged some other people take decisive steps and start their own businesses. You can definitely call Galina a workaholic! She invests all her energy in her business and seeks to see its growth. One of her dreams is to do a complete remodeling of her house, working out the interior design herself. Galina is requesting a loan of 5000 Grivnas to purchase additional merchandise and boost her sales this winter season.

loans.use: To purchase additional 50 pairs of boots

loans.name: Fabiola

texts.es:
Fabiola  vive en la calle “ 4 “  de la zona Puerto Mejillones en la ciudad de El Alto.
 
Ella es soltera vive junto a sus padres
Se dedica al comercio de artículos escolares en  una librería que instalo en su domicilio, con lo cual se ayuda económicamente para proseguir sus estudios.

El crédito lo destinara en la adquisición de mayor  mercadería (cuadernos, lápices, gomas, etc.). 
 
Es el primer  crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada lo califica para otorgarle el crédito.
texts.en:
Fabiola lives on Fourth Street in Puerto Mejillones in the city of El Alto.

She is single and lives with her parents. She sells school supplies from a bookstore setup in her home which economically supports her own studies.

She intends to use this loan for the acquisition of more merchandise (notebooks, pencils, erasers, etc.).

This is the first loan with Impro. The evaluation deemed her qualified to receive the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase articles for her bookstore such as pencils, erasers, notebooks, etc.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Caty Liz

texts.es:
Caty es socia del Banco Comunal San Gabriel.
Caty es conviviente, tiene 23 años y 1 hijo de 4 meses.
Caty tiene su negocio de venta de cosméticos, empezó con este negocio hace ya 2 años y medio, ella  reparte los productos que le piden a través de su catálogo. 
Caty necesita un préstamo de 400 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de sus productos de belleza para tener un stock.
Caty sueña con construir su casa y ser independiente más adelante..
texts.en:
Caty is a member of the communal bank San Gabriel. Caty has partner, is 23 years old and one son of 4 months. Caty owns her own cosmetics business. He started this business 2 and a half years ago. She delivers products that are purchased by catalog. Caty needs a loan of $150 USD which she will use to purchase her beauty products in order to have good stock. Caty hopes to build a home and eventually become independent.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock beauty products

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is married with six children and lives in Mbengwi, a rural town about an hour outside of Bamenda, Cameroon.  Mary plans to buy and sell palm oil and farm on land she already owns.  She will divide her loan between purchasing palm oil, paying for the cultivation of her farm land, and spending on transportation.  She plans to contribute 250,000 CFA (approximately $500 USD) of her own savings towards her business plans.

This is Mary`s fourth loan from GHAPE; she has been a member since 2004.  From her past experience, palm oil is in high demand in her area and she is confident that she can sell it quite quickly.
